I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the... School for the Quarter ended... 19...

Teachers: Mr. Johnson, of the... P.O. Address:... Dated: January 1st, 19...

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the Instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent.

Dated: January 12th, 19...

Agents should see that full explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks", if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names of other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The Quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter sent in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not large enough to contain all the necessary columns, fill in the form, pagging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days' attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

Caughnawaga, July 9, 1934.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I beg to inform you that Margaret Regis, teacher of Primary Class, in Kateri School, will probably have to give up teaching for at least one year. Her health is very poor.

Should she not be prepared to resume her duties next September, would the Department authorize me to hire Violet Snow to replace her? Violet obtained her Superior Diploma from Montreal University three years ago.

Annie Snow, Violet's sister, teacher of Primary Class in Eastern School for six years, also has her Superior Diploma and receives but $650 per year, whereas Miss Regis' salary is $750. Miss Snow often expressed the wish to get as much as Miss Regis, $750. I submit her request to your consideration.

Please accept kind regards from

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 12, 1934.

Reverend and Dear Sister:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to a proposed change in the teaching staff of the Caughnawaga R. C. schools.

As I personally informed you, any change in staff at an Indian day school must now be submitted to the Superintendent General for his approval. I would, therefore, appreciate your advising me as soon as you are certain whether or not Miss Regis intends to give up duties this year. Your letter does not state definitely if she has decided to quit. On receipt of this information, I will submit the matter to the Minister's office, and I do not anticipate there will be any difficulty in having Miss Violet Snow appointed to succeed her.

Owing to present regulations, I regret that it is not possible to make any change in salaries. Consequently, Miss Annie Snow's salary cannot be increased to $750 a year. For the past two years, very definite instructions have been given that no teacher's salary can be increased. It might be possible, in the event of Miss Violet Snow being appointed, to start her at $650 and pay Miss Annie Snow $750. This would not make any change in the total salaries at the Caughnawaga schools, and, at the same time as Miss Violet Snow is only commencing, she is possibly not entitled to start at the higher salary rate.

As mentioned above, you should let me know definitely your wishes in the matter at as early a date as possible, in order that we may follow the procedure which we are required to do.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Sister Mary Francis,
Supervising Principal,
R. C. Indian Day Schools,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.
Ottawa, August 3rd, 1934.

Reverend and Dear Sister,

I trust that you and Sister Mary Francis reached home safely and was very much pleased to have the opportunity of meeting you.

You will remember that I mentioned to you that, owing to recent regulations, we are endeavouring to regularize the positions held by Mr. Albany Robert, Mr. Joseph Gatien and Mrs. Joseph Gatien.

We have already received cards from the above, but it is necessary for us to have application forms. I enclose three copies in English and three copies in French.

Please arrange to have them complete the form, giving the information requested and return same to the Department as soon as you can conveniently do so. It is not necessary to fill in one form in French and one form in English. Only one form for each is necessary but the two different kinds are sent so that they can reply either in French or in English.

You will note that I have marked the first three questions on each form "do not answer". We will complete the information required in regard to these three questions.

You will, also, note on page 6 that, when either one of them signs, it is necessary to have a statutory declaration taken before a Notary Public or Justice of the Peace. In this connection, I may say that it will be sufficient to have Mr. Letourneau sign each of the three forms.

You understand that it is not a case of written examinations but these forms are required as a matter of record and you should so explain to each of the three concerned. I realize that these forms are not exactly applicable to the positions they hold, but the same question is asked of all applicants and the same form used. Any questions that do not apply to their particular position need not be answered. I am sorry to give you this trouble but I feel that you can explain the form to them fully and assist them in completing same.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Sister Cleophas,
R. C. Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga, Que.

MEMORANDUM:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School, No. 305.

Sister M. Leander, a member of the teaching staff at the above-mentioned school was obliged to give up duties on March 31, 1940, and no further payment should be made to her.

She has been succeeded by Sister M. Cecilia whose appointment dates from April 1, 1940, and who will be allowed the same salary as the previous teacher; namely, $700.00 a year. The name of Sister M. Cecilia should appear on the April and subsequent pay lists until further advised.

I enclose copy of letter of appointment and staff questionnaire will be forwarded to you when received.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Dear Sister Jean de Dieu:

I was advised by the Treasury Branch this morning that several of the Sisters have expressed a willingness to have an amount deducted from their cheques each month in order to purchase war savings certificates.

It may be a mistake on the part of the Treasury Branch but the information they have is that these certificates, when issued, are to be registered in the name of "General Economie". If I am correct this simply means General Treasurer but does not say Treasurer of what organization.

My own suggestion would be to have them registered in the official name of your Order. By so doing there will be no difficulty in establishing ownership whenever the certificates are due for payment. If you wish to follow my suggestion it would be appreciated if you would let me know immediately the name under which your Order holds its charter. Possibly this is Sisters of St. Anne but I thought it preferable to obtain this information from you.

Yours truly,

Rev. Sister Jean de Dieu,
Principal,
Caughnawaga R.C. School,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We wish to take this opportunity to thank you and every member of the Department who in any way helped in obtaining a new roof for our convent. We certainly appreciate it and we are still hoping that something will be done to the porch. Are we expecting too much?

Several times we have taken up the matter of having a mimeograph for the R.C.I.S., and every time we were assured that something would be done about it. We are not asking for a new one but we certainly could put a duplicating machine to good use. For example, many hours have been spent in searching records in order to make up a History of Caughnawaga. We had planned to mimeograph these notes and place them in the pupils' hands. Many other projects could be handled in the same way. Could you lend a helping hand in obtaining one for us?

We thank you for your kind attention to all these matters and we beg to remain

September 19, 1942.

My dear Sister:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 17th instant, in which you ask for authority to spend a sum of approximately $100.00 for sewing materials, supplies, etc., for the promotion of vocational instruction at your school.

It will be in order for you to make these purchases from time to time as the need arises, on the understanding that the total expenditure will not exceed the amount stated.

I was glad to learn that you were satisfied with the new roof on the teacherage. A few weeks ago I discussed with the Surveys & Engineering Branch the desirability of undertaking certain repairs to the porch. I regret to state, however, that in view of existing conditions there is not even a remote possibility that these repairs can be undertaken at this date. This applies also to the mimeograph unit referred to in the second last paragraph of your letter. Few people, other than the officials at Ottawa, realize the difficulty we are experiencing these days in securing certain supplies. I have in mind particularly typewriters, furnaces for Indian day schools and repairs for such furnaces. As a matter of fact all of us must realize that this nation is fighting for its existence and that the days ahead will demand the exercise of a great deal of self-sacrifice and the exercise of a great deal of patience on the part of all of us. We are constantly reminded, however, that at the end of the war there are likely to be huge surpluses of supplies that will be, at that date, available for our schools. In the meantime it would appear that we can do nothing, other than to make the best possible use of the limited supplies at our disposal.

Yours truly,

Sister M. Jean de Dieu,
Principal,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

While checking school supplies in all classes, we find that there are still many items missing. We are attaching a copy of these articles called for on our requisition for the scholastic year 1945-1946.

Furthermore, we have had a long conference with Mr. Wescott, the Inspector, regarding a programme to be followed by our Ninth Year. This year, we have twelve boys and five girls in this class and if you approve, we would attempt the following programme with them:

1. Religion - Scripture - Liturgy (all books on hand)

2. English Grammar and Composition:
   "An English Highway" -- Moon & McKay
   (Published by Longman's, Green & Co.)

3. English Literature: "Loyola Book of Verse"
   (Published by the Loyola University Press)

4. High School Algebra -- Crawford
   (Published by Macmillan Co., Toronto)

5. French (At the Indians' special request)
   (See letter attached)

Commercial Geography, History, Science, etc. will be taken care of by mimeograph copies for this year.
Mr. Wescott and we also believe that this programme will be an immediate preparation for our boys going to Loyola in preparation for their technical course later on. Our girls also would thereby be saving one year of high school while training as teachers.

You may be interested to know that one of our war veterans, eighteen years old and wounded overseas, came to beg us to accept him in school. He says he is willing to follow the pupils everywhere as long as he gets the knowledge he refused when he was younger.

Our registration so far is 352 pupils, more than fifty above last year's. Our "store" classroom is coming along well. The pupils' desks and the blackboard came in last Saturday. We thank you for all these supplies. Will you kindly tell us if we may count on the additional textbooks mentioned in this letter?

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

I desire to refer to the requisition forwarded by the Principal of the Caughnawaga R.C. School.

Some of the books requested appear different from those supplied in previous years, and, before placing an order for them, I would appreciate further information.

1. 45 General History (Modern World).

Is this a Canadian or an American publication? In what grades is it proposed to use this book? From what firm in Canada can the book be secured?

2. 6 Language Work Books (1-2-3)
   6 " " " (#4 - 5)

The different publishing firms have different books of this kind. Please let me know the name of the publisher whose books the Sisters prefer.

3. 40 Directed Language Practice Workbook Grade 7
   38 " " " " " " 8

Similar information should be given regarding these books as has been requested regarding the Language Workbooks.

4. 30 Dominion High School Arithmetic
   18 School Arithmetic - Interim.

The number of High School Arithmetics requested appears large. Will there be 30 children in this school taking
high school work next year? The name of the publisher of the Interim Arithmetic should also be given.

5. 45 Junior Science for Secondary Schools, Part I. (Pitman & Sons)

I am under the impression that this is an American publication. Several Canadian publishers have excellent Science series. Would it not be possible for the Principal to select books published by a Canadian publisher?

6. 700 sheets construction paper 22 x 28.

The approximate cost of these would be $58.00. Would it be possible for the Principal to reduce her request?

7. We have recently been informed that the Philips Atlas is out of print.

You may purchase 24 rug needles and 40 loose-leaf binders.

Please show this letter to the Principal as soon as possible and let me have her reply.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sister Albertus:

We have received your requisition dated June 15th and are arranging to supply your requirements in most of the items. However, there are several items which we do not find in the list of Textbooks approved for English Catholic Schools for 1947-48, and these are not being ordered. These are as follows:

History of Canada Elem. (CSV)
Lessons in English Elem. (BCS)
Reading Development for Grade VI
Reading Tests for above
Play Workbooks for Juniors
" " for Older Children
Directed Language Practice Workbook
Canadian Practice and Testing Workbooks
New Progress Arithmetic Workbooks
Geography Workbooks
History Workbooks.

The school Bulletin for September will contain a list of workbooks in Language which will be available shortly.

With reference to your request for pictures for class study, it is noted that you list a catalogue number but neglect to state the name of the company who supplies these pictures.

We also note that you have requested a set of the Book of Knowledge, although two sets have just recently been sent to you.
In your requisition of June 17th you ask for large quantities of library books which we are making available to our schools. I would refer you to the June issue of the Bulletin, Item No. 60, in which we clearly lay down the scale of issue for these books. From the quantities ordered, it would seem evident that the Sisters who prepared this requisition have not read this item very carefully. As we are endeavouring to supply not only our large schools, but also our smaller schools with library books, you will realize that it would be impossible to provide the quantities which you have requested.

Before we can order a Gestetner Duplicating Machine for your school, I would ask you to let me know what type of hectograph or duplicating machine, if any, you are at present using at the Caughnawaga School.

The Rhythm Band outfit is not being allowed.

A decision has not yet been reached regarding the Catechisms to be used in future in Roman Catholic schools throughout Canada, and we are, therefore, not supplying the catechisms which you request.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We wish to express our deep appreciation for the very interesting books issued by the Canadian Legion Educational Services, and sent to us by the Department a few weeks ago, also for the items called for in our requisition and which have already begun to come in.

Yes, Mr. Phelan, we are aware that some of the books which we ordered are not now approved for English Catholic Schools; however these books have already been in the list of textbooks and they still are of such great help to the teachers and pupils that we thought we could call for them again. We accept your decision in the matter but feel sorry about the "Canadian Practice and Testing Workbooks". May we call your attention to the fact that these workbooks form part of the textbook "Canadian Problem and Practice by Smith, etc." which is actually the Arithmetic textbook approved for English Catholic Schools? Would it be possible also to receive a dozen or so of the Geography and History workbooks for the use of the teachers in the classroom?

With reference to our request for pictures for class study, we stated the name of the company from which these may be had on page eight of our requisition. It is "Moyer's School Supplies."

We made out our requisition in April; then we were not aware that we were to receive two lovely sets of "The Book of Knowledge" in the following month. The pupils and teachers love them.

Now I must offer my apologies for the "large quantities" of library books published in the June bulletin and I am the one who made the blunder and not our teachers here. I am enclosing a new list for these books and trust your customary kindness will find a way to obtain these attractive books for our classes.

We have no hectograph or duplicating machine of any kind in our schools. We use the simple repeater pads or "Ditto Duplicating Film" sent us by you with our school supplies. We should find it very useful to get a Gestetner Duplicating Machine for the schools.
I wish to express our sincere thanks, once more, for giving authorization for the painting of our house. We have just heard that Mr. Lamotot's prices for the paint have been accepted so we hope the work will soon begin. It is no luxury, I assure you, Mr. Phelan.

I have just given Reverend Father Lalonde the names of the pupils who wish to obtain a grant to continue their education in some college or convent in Sept. The parents and teachers will be very grateful to you for what you will kindly do to allow our pupils to continue their education.

With renewed thanks, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

Mr. Bernard Neary,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

We wish to extend our sincere thanks, once more, to you and the members of the Department for the increases in salary we have recently received.

You must be aware that many of the school articles asked in our requisition of last April have not yet been received. We have already mentioned this point in our letter of Sept. 8th, stating the urgent need we had of pencils, rulers, etc. We also asked authorization to order Latin and French books. May we hope to receive these articles and books soon? There are also cleaning articles for our residence and for the schools which we are also hoping you will grant authorization to Mr. Lanctot of St. Isidore to purchase for us as in former years.

Dear Sir, we are taking the liberty of enclosing a list of books which we would very much need for our classes. Most of these books were also requisitioned in April. We are sending you, too, a copy of the much needed articles mentioned above.

Owing to our small classrooms in our two schools, our physical culture teacher suggests to combine two or three groups together and give her lessons in the Parish Hall. We often use this Parish Hall for school purposes. Do you think, Sir, that a rent could be paid by the Department to Father Lalonde?

Our Domestic Science Teacher finds it very hard to buy all the material she needs for her sewing class with One Hundred and Thirty Dollars. She asks whether this allowance could be increased.
I believe that during one of the last visits of the Delegation of Caughnawaga to the Members of the Department that it was asked that the grounds of our old Senior School be levelled. May I be allowed to stress the need of this when we wish our pupils to meet together for field days and for sports matches of all kinds. We are trying to put into effect the House System for games and school activities as suggested in the splendid Indian Bulletins which we receive. We have already expressed our praise for these bulletins in the past school year. We still find them enlightening, valuable and interesting.

Speaking of our Senior School, at this time last year we were most certain that our new school would be well on its way during this Fall of 1947. May we still cherish the hope of seeing its walls rise very soon?

We derived much benefit from the conferences given in Montreal on the 16th and 19th of Sept. and which you kindly allowed us to attend. Our Inspector, Mr. Wescott gave us splendid talks.

With renewed thanks for this privilege and much hope of receiving a favorable reply to the above requests, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal

N.B. We realize that the books we wish to get from the Montreal Book Room amounts to a high sum, about $16.00. Would it be easier for you and for us if we made four or five bills of between $30.00 to $90.00 worth of books at a time?

Mr. Bernard Henry,

Dear Sir,

We are deeply grateful for the kind attention given our supplementary requisition.

Yes, we did notice you have ordered only three copies of "Europe Before Modern Times" but though we made a request of fourteen of these in our requisition of last April, we have not received them. During Mr. Doucet's last visit to us, we spoke to him about this, also about the "Junior Science", Book II, listed in the program of books for the Catholic High Schools of Que. May we hope that you will have these fourteen "Europe etc." and 36 "Junior Science, Part II" ordered soon from the Montreal Book Room?

We thank you very much for the copy of the list of pictures to be ordered from Moyer's and the other books from the Montreal Book Room. We have begun to receive a few from the latter place and I assure you that our teachers and pupils are very happy.

We are still anxiously awaiting for the 80 Bailey Writing Books, Part I, and the 200 copies of Part II. Our pupils of the lower grades are in need of them.

The basketball, bats, etc., have been received and every one is much pleased with them. We shall take much care of these sports objects.

Dear Sir, has any decision been taken about the rent to be paid for the use of the Parish Hall and about an increase
of the yearly allowance given to our Domestic Science teacher? I have already mentioned these two points in my letter of Oct. 14th.

With renewed thanks for your kindness, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal

INTRODUCTION

It is admitted that the united strength of Steel and Concrete, when correctly proportioned, exceeds many times the sum of their individual strength.

Keeping this in mind, it stands to reason that steel, inserted in the cement mortar joint of brick work, will have the effect of strengthening the joint to a very great degree.

In seeking a suitable form for this steel it was decided to use it as a wire mesh of 14 G. wire with a \( \frac{5}{8} \) mesh, as this permeates the cement thoroughly and most nearly approaches the ideal reinforcement.

TESTS

In order to test the effectiveness of this theory the following wall was built. An eight inch cavity wall was erected consisting of one wall 4" thick, a cavity of \( \frac{1}{2} \)" and a brick-on-edge or 2\( \frac{1}{2} \)" wall. This wall was supported on two piers ten feet apart, and it had a projecting part or cantilever five feet long.

There were no ties of any description between the walls, but the reinforcement was inserted in each mortar joint and carried the full length of the wall through the piers.

The illustration shows the load on the wall; 17,111 lbs. on the span and 4,088 lbs. on the cantilever.

The loads were distributed, but care was taken to keep them inside the line of the piers. With this load there was no sign of fracture or weakness, and after waiting for a time it was decided to knock the test down by using a batten as a ram.

This was accomplished after considerable effort by two men.

This test was carried out in a Montreal Builder's yard in November and December of 1908.

A further test was made to destruction to find the lateral resistance of a half brick wall. A piece of wall half a brick thick, measuring 3 ft. long and 2 ft. wide was built in 3-1
cement mortar, and reinforced every course in a similar manner to the previous test. After standing for ten days it was laid on its side and supported at both ends having a bearing of \( \frac{1}{2} \).

It was then loaded with bricks and failed under a load of 4,144 lbs.

The illustration shows a photo of the above mentioned piece of wall after failure. It will be noted that the bricks failed before the mortar joint. Compare this with a wall without reinforcement placed in the same position. It would hardly support itself.

POINTS REGARDING THE USE OF REINFORCEMENT IN BRICK WORK

The hollow or cavity brick wall is probably the best type of insulation known in building construction.

A hollow brick wall secures the building against heat, cold, and damp, and when used for partitions is sound-proof, and fireproof.

The ordinary brick cavity wall is expensive, but when built on the H. B. System can be built cheaply, because reinforced brick walls by reason of their great strength in resisting tensile and lateral stresses, do not require to be of the same thickness as ordinary walls, whose strength is only in proportion to their weight.

Thin brick walls are only as strong as their foundation for weight-carrying purposes. Should the foundation settle, cracks will appear throughout the building.

By using H. B. Reinforcement, Architects and Engineers will insure their building against settlement, cracks, and bulging, add 50 per cent. to its life, reduce the cost of maintenance and repairs, and render the building monolithic and fireproof.

In a recent copy of a magazine devoted to the uses of cement, a series of tests of the best fire-resisting materials is recorded. After describing the various mixtures used in the tests and their fire-resisting properties, the engineer under whose supervision the tests were held, came to the conclusion that "Brick Panel probably withstood the tests better than the other materials."

These tests were held under the supervision of Mr. Richard L. Humphrey, of the Structural Materials Laboratories of the U. S. Geological Survey, St. Louis.

PARTITIONS

For partition work this reinforcement is specially suitable. Partitions so constructed are cheaper than any form of partition on the market. They impose no load on the floors, are self-supporting between the points of support, will support a load of 200 lbs. for every course of reinforcement, have a lateral resistance of over 200 lbs. per foot superficial, and in addition are fire and vermin proof.

A very light and useful partition can be obtained by building the brick-on-edge, and a brick-on-edge partition reinforced with H. B. is stronger than an ordinary 9" wall.

USED AS A BONDING FIN

When used as a bonding fin between concrete work and brick, this material is extremely useful.

The general way of using it for this purpose is to insert a double piece in the concrete, and leave two loose ends to be built into the brick.
In some cases this process may be reversed and the brick built up first and used as a retaining wall for the concrete. The loose ends of the reinforcement bind themselves into the concrete, thus saving the cost of wooden forms.

**PROPERTIES CLAIMED FOR H. B.**

The following properties are claimed for H. B. reinforcement.

1. It gives a fire-proof, damp-proof, and sound-proof wall when used for cavity walls.
2. It has a strength in proportion to its height.
3. H. B. Walls only require a foundation at points.
4. Any brick will do, and any bricklayer can lay it.
5. It may be used over door and window openings instead of steel beams or brick arches.
6. In many cases a saving of 30 to 50 per cent. can be effected by its use.
7. In all cases it will add strength to brick walls.

**SPECIFICATIONS**

In specifying this material, state clearly that H. B WIRE MESH REINFORCEMENT will be inserted in every course (or as often as required) and that it is supplied by Francis Hankin, 231 Coristine Building, Montreal.

**GENERAL**

In a pamphlet of this nature it is possible only to give a very short description of the various properties of the material and the uses to which it is adapted. Reinforced Brickwork can never be surpassed.

Brick has stood the test of ages, while concrete has stood the test of months only.

The foregoing all tends to convince one that reinforced brick walls possess all the advantages of reinforced concrete, in addition to which they are dry instead of damp, fire-proof instead of fire resisting, cost half as much and are not unsightly, while atmospheric disintegration is practically unknown.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 12th inst., No.154172-5A, relative to the expenses, amounting to $10.50, in the sale of the old girls' school-house at Caughnawaga, allow me to inform you that it was announced at the time of the sale, in English, French and Indian, that the expenses of the sale, amounting to $10.50, would be payable by the purchaser in addition to the price of the sale.

There were at the place of the sale some white men residing outside of the reserve who desired to purchase the building, and I thought it right to send the Department the net amount of the sale; but I see that I went too far outside of my powers, and as I was new in the position, Mr. Blain, it seems to me, ought to have informed me; but, far from that, it was he who strongly advised me to make out this list of expenses, saying that he was acting in his capacity as notary public, and that he would charge $4.00 for the deed.

I went to Caughnawaga on a Sunday, authorized by letter from the Department dated May 31, No.154172-5, to announce the sale at the church-door. It was for this trip that I charged $1.50 as also for the promissory notes of $1.00.

I acted in good faith in this matter and followed the advice of Mr. Blain, my superior.

If after these explanations you think that the Department ought to get this money, I will collect from those who received it for their work and will send the amount to the Department.

I doubt very much that Michel Montour told you
that it was understood that the expenses of the sale were to be paid in addition to the purchase price as announced; and this same Michel Montour since his return from Ottawa has been going all over the village of Caughnawaga announcing to the Iroquois that the assistant agent had obtained money under false pretences, besides that this had been told him by officers of Indian Affairs at Ottawa.

I thought that I ought to have been permitted as assistant agent and new in my position to give explanations to my superiors in the Department in order to clear myself and to correct my error, if possible, before a charge should be made against me to the Indians.

Yours, &c.,

Lorenzo Letourneau
Asst. Agent

Mr. Matthews made me notice that there was no drain along the road in front of the School and that in the spring water will probably damage the verandah and cellar windows. L'INSTRUCTION CHEZ LES INDIENS DE CAUGHNAWAGA

L'honorable Frank Oliver, ministre de l'Intérieur, fait construire deux écoles dans ce pittoresque et intéressant village. -- De la place pour trois cents enfants.

Trois cents enfants pourront trouver place dans cette école. Les plans ont été examinés par les représentants de la commission des écoles de la province d'Ontario. La hauteur de chaque pilier est de quinze pieds, et les planchers sont soutenus par des poutres en fer. Tout est absolument conforme aux lois provinciales concernant la construction des écoles.

La nouvelle école est moins spacieuse. Cent jeunes filles y auront à être admises. C'est un édifice de bois de deux étages. Elle sera dirigée par Mlle Young.

Les constructeurs sont MM. Lafleur et Laberge de Lévis. Ces messieurs ont déjà construit le bâtiment de la résidence de Mme Young et le bâtiment de la résidence de M. Young.

L'entrée des classes dans ces deux écoles se fera au mois de janvier.

La prison qui servait d'école catholique sera bientôt démolie et reconstruite.

Il ne faut pas oublier, avant de terminer ce résumé, que le ministre de l'Intérieur M. Oliver, qui fait partie du gouvernement, et surtout M. Duncan Scott, le ministre de l'Instruction pour les Indiens, ont fait donner à ceux-ci l'instruction la plus complète possible, sans distinction de religion.

Déjà, grâce aux nombreuses écoles que le département des affaires indiennes vient de faire construire à Caughnawaga, plusieurs jeunes indiens ont obtenu d'excellentes éducation, ou dans nos grandes maisons industrielles et commerciales.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of November 24th, No. 154 172/5, in regard to the acceptance of the new schools from the contractors; I beg to inform you that on the 25th of last month the new Girls' School building was ready for occupation with the exception of the slate blackboards that were not yet fixed in place, but Mr. Lalonde stated that the blackboards were not ready to be placed before a few days more, that it could be fixed later on without disturbing the pupils, on that account I have arranged to meet with the teachers for the opening in the New Girls' School on the 28th of November, and the blackboards are not placed yet and the contractors disappeared from Caughnawaga since the 26th of last month.

The Protestant School at that time was not ready for occupation but I was supposed to be called by phone from St. Constant to Caughnawaga three or four days afterwards by the contractors. I went to Caughnawaga on the 25th, thinking that everything was completed and to have the New Protestant School opened, but I was surprised to see that the new building was locked up and informed that the contractors were gone.

The New Protestant school is not heated and I suppose that with such a cold weather it can be damaging to the plasterings.

As instructed by your department I had arranged with the contractors to have the desks from the old building placed into the New one and it has not been done.

With reference to your letter of 23rd Nov. (same file No.), to the fact that only one closet was erected in connection with the Protestant School, I certify that the specifications in this respect were not carried out.

I wish your Department will notify these contractors to have the Protestant School ready for occupation in the least possible delay, and the blackboards fixed in place as specified.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM.

The account hereunder is for 24 Adjustable Desks supplied to the Continuation School on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

The Sister Superior asked that Harvard Adjustable Desks be supplied, as the pupils are adults and it was necessary to have desks that could be adjusted to the required height. Both the George M. Hendry Co., and the E. N. Moyer Co., furnished prices. The order was first placed with the Hendry Co. for 'Challenge' Adjustable Desks at $10.95 each, but they informed us that, while this line of desks appeared in their catalogue, they were unable to give delivery at the time required, namely, September 1st, when the school opened. As it was necessary to obtain desks for that date, the order was then transferred to the E. N. Moyer Co., Limited, for Harvard Adjustable Desks at $13.75 each. Owing to the demand for school desks they were the only firm that could guarantee delivery at the time required and the order was placed with them. I may say that in the new price list now submitted by the E. N. Moyer Co. the price for the type of desk supplied is $15.80.

As it was absolutely necessary to have these desks in time to open the school on the first of September and the Hendry Co. would not guarantee the time of delivery, the order was placed with the E. N. Moyer Co., who furnished the desks at the time required at a slightly higher price, but considerably less than the price now asked for the same desk. The quotation of the Globe Furniture Co., Limited, Waterloo, for the same type of desks as ordered was $14.10.

Taking into consideration the urgent need for these desks, I consider that, in placing the order with the E. N. Moyer Co., the very best price was obtained under the circumstances.

Attention of Mr. F. H. Pugnet,

I am in receipt of your submission of October 5th., File 5-7-5, relative to the purchase of desks and chairs for Caughnawaga Reserve.

For your guidance would you permit me to point out the following procedure in purchasing of supplies in future.

(1) When purchases are being made, a specification of your requirements, together with your call, and the names of firms you propose to ask should be submitted to this Commission before being sent out. This is to ensure that you will purchase from the best source of supply.

(2) After the tenders have been received by you they are scheduled by a representative of your department and a representative from this Commission.

(3) The file is then submitted to this Commission, with your recommendation, for authority to make purchase.

In connection with this purchase you will note that the E. N. Noyes Co., purchased from the manufacturer the W. F. Villas Co., Ltd., Cowansville, Que. This purchase runs into considerable money, and had it been purchased by calling tenders, it is altogether probable that your requirements could have been purchased (for less money than your now paying) from this manufacturer, knowing that he was quoting against other manufacturers.

Madam,

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 25th ultimo in which you state that only half the number of braces necessary for the desks in the Continuation School were received I have to request that you will be good enough to state definitely the number of parts of the desks which are missing. Rev. Sister Mary Gabriel,
Principal,
Caughnawaga (R.C.) Schools,
Caughnawaga, Que.
My dear Sir,

In reply to your inquiry about the desks, I should say that braces for 12 desks are missing.

I must also state that the grade of iron used in manufacturing these desks was very poor. The bolts, shafts, and the base holding the chair is of such inferior quality that two chairs are already unseverable. The pair fell right off while the pupil was sitting quickly at the desk.

We have had some trouble with the Remington typewriter. In the first place...
It was shipped to Montreal and held there until the office people found out to whom it belonged. When I learned it was at the Montreal Remington office, I asked the Manager to make the keyboard blank and send it to Caughnawaga. He did this, but when we opened the box we found no accessories whatever such as cover, oil can, book instruction book etc. I wrote to the Manager and asked if these articles had been removed in the Montreal office by mistake. He told me that there was nothing in the box when they opened it, but promised to take up the matter with the Ottawa office.

It is customary for typewriter concerns to guarantee their machines for one year and attend to all repairs.
free of charge during that interval. I should suggest that the Department notify the different Concerns from whom they have purchased type-writers in Ottawa to instruct their Montreal Agencies to look after the type-writers in use here until October 1921.

I have used the Underwood machine only and am not at all familiar with the Remington so it would do me a great favor if a man was sent here to examine the machine and give instructions for its use.

Thanking you kindly,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours cordially,

Sister M. Gabriel
Principal

My dear Sir,

I enclose, herewith, a list of desks and furnishings needed for the new class in Boys' School, being held in the lower flat of the Delorme Residence.

By way of explanation I would say that I intend taking the 22 double desks now used in the Primary Girls school to this new room, and replace them there with single desks. My reason for doing this is two-fold; the girls are more careful than boys and convenience in handling single desks is much greater than in moving double desks every time we need the Assembly Hall.

The Department shipped 24 single desks No. 6 in March to Girls School, but there were neither backs nor fronts to these, so much space was lost. I have figured out that with 11 complete new desks, and backs and fronts as indicated, I will have a seating capacity of 42 pupils in this class room.

Further more in 3rd Class of Girls School 6 fronts and 6 backs would give us 12 more places in the school; it is for this reason I have ordered them in place of complete desks.

I would request that this year we be allowed to purchase two good clocks, one for the lower hall of each school near the main entrance. These would serve to regulate the clocks in the class rooms, which just now keep all kinds of time. All bells would be rung according to the clock, and eliminate the conflicts of tardiness; for often two pupils coming in at the same time are marked one "early" and the other "on time," because one clock was fast and the other slow.

I would also request that a good large gong be placed in each of the large schools. The little hand bells are not heard at any distance away, and I feel sure punctuality would be greatly increased by such a reminder.

I did not order a desk or chair for the teacher in this new school, because I retained 2 desks and 3 chairs from the Soldier's Civil Re-establishment, as well as a quantity of blackboard material.

Mr. Vail went to Montreal twice in the
interests of the schools, but he could get very little from the Soldier's Civil Re Establishment as all was ordered shipped to the Marine Department; he selected a few tools, however which will be of use.

With further reference to the type writers I would gladly accept four Underwood if possible, but providing they are in good condition & do not mind the make. The Underwood seems the slowest, near and dear much better than any other machine.

My idea is to turn the upper flat of the Alzheimer Residence into a type writing room. We will dispense with the chairs and tables and use tables etc secured from the Soldier's Civil Re Establishment.

I hope you will be able to send the order for the desks early enough that we may have them installed for the opening of school in September.

Yours very cordially,

OTTAWA, June 11th, 1921.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing a list of the desks and furnishings required to provide extra classroom accommodation for the boys' school on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

It is noted that you will arrange for the transposition of the double desks now in use in the primary class of the girls' school to the new classroom, and with the addition of the desks now asked for and the front and rear seats, you will be able to provide seating accommodation to meet all requirements. Before we place an order for the front and rear seats required by you, you will be good enough to state whether the sizes will match the desks that were recently supplied and which were ordered from the W. F. Vilas Co., Ogdensburg, P.Q., as it will be necessary to obtain front and rear seats to match the desks for which they are intended. A slightly lower price can be obtained from this firm, and if the fronts and rears manufactured by them will match the various types of desk in use, an order will be placed with them for the number requisitioned by you.

It is noted that you also require one right and one left casting for a #6 desk. Kindly state if these castings are required for a desk manufactured by the above firm, and if not, for which make of desk these castings are required.

You may arrange for the purchase of eight window curtains, one clock, one thermometer, one waste paper basket, one water pail, one wash basin, one soap dish, drinking cups, roller towel fixtures and one pencil sharpener.

You may also arrange for the purchase of two stoves of a size and type suitable to heat the building, and also for the necessary stove pipes, and when these are received, you should arrange to have them set up. You may also purchase two coal scuttles, two shovels, one axe, two brooms, two dust pans, and one stove brush.

You may also purchase two clocks, one each to be placed in the lower halls of the boy's and girls' schools. While care should be taken to see that good clocks are purchased, they should be as reasonably priced as possible.

Before making the purchase of the above supplies you will be good enough to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and in each case purchase from the dealer quoting the lowest price. You should attach to the accounts a memorandum giving the names of the firms asked to quote, and the prices quoted by each.

The Department will leave the purchase of the above articles in your hands, to make the best arrangements you can, and to secure the lowest possible prices for the most serviceable articles.

Regarding your request that a large gong be obtained for each school, I will be pleased if you will obtain a price for these gongs, and the cost of installing same, and inform the Department, when your request will receive consideration.

The Department will place an order with the Government Stationery Office for four Underwood typewriters to be sent to your address. These machines have been taken over from the Department of Soldiers' Civil Re-establishment, and have been put in good repair and are practically as good as new. The type of the standard keyboard type, and a set of Munson's rubber keys for each machine will also be sent. Before placing the order, however, I would like you to state whether you require the keyboards of these machines to contain English or French characters.

As soon as the information asked for regarding the typewriters and the front and rear desks is received, an order will be placed for both at once. I will be pleased if you will let us have this information as soon as possible.

My dear Sir,

In reply to your inquiry regarding desks I would say that the backs and fronts will match those recently ordered from the W.T. Villar Co., Comancheville. The six fronts and backs No. 5 single desks to complete the 3rd Class Girls School may also be purchased from the W.T. Villar Co. Those we have are not the same make, but the difference is so slight that it will not matter. The R & L Caltinge are for one single desk No. 6. It is to replace those broken in the last shipment from Comancheville.

I will be pleased to have the French accents on the typewriters, if possible, as it will be very helpful. My intention is to have the children become familiar with both languages. It is a necessity here.

I would request that I may be allowed to have a repair man come from Montreal during the summer to
look over our typ machines, and put them in good working order for the new school year.

I really do not care to have the Munsen rubber caps on our machines, but if the key boards could be made blank instead I would prefer it. We teach the touch method, and with a visible keyboard it is much harder than with a blank one. Any ordinary repair man will make a key board blank in a very short time.

Eight of our pupils, five boys and three girls, will receive their Diploma for Typewriting. Some have attained a speed of 47 net words a minute on a blank machine. Seven of them write with ease 100 words a minute in Short-hand. They will undergo their final test tomorrow and receive their Diplomas, if their work is accepted by the Montreal Institute.

My Agent Brossard very kindly donated a gold medal for the best pupil in Arithmetic. To determine this I requested Mr. Brossard to give an examination himself, which he accordingly did. Eighteen pupils took the test and four obtained 100%.
I then submitted these four to another test and one boy came out with 95%. The children showed great interest in their work, and were very enthusiastic.

I purchased prizes to the amount of $60.00 as per allowance, and will forward accounts in a few days.

I shall attend to the other matters and obtain competitive prices for clocks, lamps etc., as soon as the schools are closed. But now the final examinations promotions etc. take up every moment of my time.

Thinking you may kindly,

& am. dear Sir,

Yours very cordially,

Sister Mary Gabriel

OTTAWA, July 4th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to request that upon the occasion of your next visit to Caughnawaga you will arrange to have the following improvements carried out in the building leased from Mr. John Delormier to be used as extra class-room accommodation, viz:

(1) The purchase of sufficient 1/2" V.J. to finish the upper story to make it suitable for a Typewriting Department; also the purchase of sufficient paint to give both the upstairs and downstairs two coats, and you should also arrange for the necessary labour in having the work performed.

(2) It will also be necessary to fit up the stable in order to provide a place for the winter supply of wool and coal, and you may arrange for the purchase of the necessary plank to provide a floor, and any other material required.

(3) It will be necessary to fit up toilets, and you should arrange to have this work done, and any material required purchased.

(4) A gate is required to connect this extra class-room with the boys' school. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of this gate.

(5) The Sister Superior requests that a wall in the Continuation School be removed at the rear to provide increased class-room accommodation. You should arrange to have this wall removed and an archway built in, with sufficient support to carry the weight of the ceiling.

(6) The walls of this school require a coat of paint. You may purchase a sufficient quantity of paint and arrange to have the work done.

(7) The Sister Superior states that the black-boards in this school are too high. If possible, you may arrange to have them lowered, or a platform installed, and you should also arrange to have any black-board material which the Principal has on hand installed in the schools where required.

(8) You may purchase sufficient varnish to varnish the desks in all the class-rooms, and arrange to have the work done.

In the purchase of any material, you should, as far as possible, obtain competitive prices and purchase the lumber and paint required from the firm quoting the lowest price.

On July 4th I was authorized to perform certain work at the Government school buildings on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, and I at once applied to the Accounts Branch which immediately took the matter up with the Purchasing Commission for obtaining the materials required, the estimated cost of which is about $100.00.

The work was urgently needed and had to be done during the school holidays. These materials have not yet been received, and a good amount of time has thus been lost owing to the fact that the men did not have the necessary materials on hand. I wish, therefore, to inform the Department that if this proceeding is to be followed every time small quantities of materials are required, I shall not be held responsible for the delay in the performance of the work and also the cost of same. Unless I am given more latitude in the execution of my work outside of the office I regret to say that it is almost impossible for me to transact business to the best advantage of the Department. If thoroughly examined the above case will prove that there is no practical economy in delaying the purchase of a small quantity of materials, especially the kind generally required in our works.

Departmental Engineer.

My dear Sir,

I take the liberty of asking you to kindly inquire if there are any other typewriters available from the D.A.C.R. or at the Stationery Department in Ottawa. I would be grateful indeed for two more machines. Underwood's preferred. There are twenty-four pupils in regular attendance and the practice has to be broken up into three parts while if we had two more machines it could be divided into two parts only. This would facilitate the work greatly. I know you will do what lies in your power to help us out.

I am submitting for your approval a monthly report card which I would like to have printed for distribution in the six higher classes of the School. The supply we have is exhausted, and I have changed the form somewhat to meet the conditions of the schools today. I would request you to authorize me to have the work done and I will see to it that the very lowest price will be obtained.

I would furthermore ask to be allowed to have the French characters placed on three or four of our typewriters. As it is there is not one machine with the accents used in writing French and I think it quite necessary that the children should be trained to write French as readily as English.

I am pleased to tell you that the children are doing wonderfully well in school. They are showing the greatest interest in their work and the attendance is all that possibly can be desired.

Thanking you for your past kindness

I am, dear Sir,
Yours very cordially,

[Signature]
Principal.

Ottawa.
OTTAWA, October 12th, 1921.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland of this Department, requesting that two more typewriters be supplied for the use of the continuation school on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that an order is being placed with the Government Stationery Office to ship to your address, Adirondack Junction, P.Q., 2 Underwood typewriters from the supply on hand which was taken over from the D.S.C.R. The French characters have been ordered to be supplied with these typewriters.

You may arrange to have the French characters placed on a number of the typewriters which you have at present on hand. You should obtain these from some dealer in Montreal, and account, in duplicate, should be obtained covering the cost, which you should hand to Mr. Agent Brossard to certify and send to the Department for payment.

Regarding the monthly report cards required for distribution to the pupils in the six higher classes of the Caughnawaga Schools, I beg to say that you may arrange to have a number of these cards printed. The sample which you forwarded in your letter is being returned herewith. Accounts should be obtained covering the cost of the printing of these cards and they should be handed to Mr. Agent Brossard in the usual manner.

The Department is very pleased to note that there is such a large and regular attendance of Indian children at the schools under your charge, and that the work is progressing satisfactorily.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sister Mary Gabriel,
Principal, Indian Schools,

Enclosed voucher in favour of Alfred's for merchandise supplied to clothe Indian children of Couch-nesse. It was not practicable to ask for tenders in these kinds of purchases.

As to the family Benedict mentioned in your letter of mine of January last, I beg to say that there are 3 children of school age: One boy 12 years, a girl 11, and another boy 8. They have absolutely no clothing and need to be fitted up completely. They have no shoes or other clothing and have been kept in the house all winter. The boy, aged 12 attended school a few weeks in June and September. He is absolutely illiterate, can hardly pick a few simple words. The girl, 11, went to school a few weeks in June.
Sir,

and knows nothing. The other boy never attended school.

The boys should need overcoats, caps, mitts, shoes, rubber stockings, underwear and a suit of clothes or pants and sweaters. The girl would need cloak, dress, underwear, shoes, stockings, mitts, rubber cap, etc. I should judge that it will not be possible to clothe these children for less than $25.00 each; and I really do not know if I could get them fitted off for that amount. Sir:-

The water pipe supplying water to the closet of the girls' school at Caughnawaga is now thawed out, and I am informed that it must be broken somewhere, and cannot be used on account of the water lost through such break. Mr. Viau tells me that he can locate the place where the pipe is broken by unearthing it at the corner near the church, and that he could repair it himself. I prefer to consult you before authorizing such expenditure.

I consider that it is absolutely necessary that this pipe should be laid deeper so as to avoid the danger of frost, and this work should be done before the macadamized road is finished in front of the church. I am told that this pipe is only one (1") inch in diameter, and it would be preferable to have a larger pipe.

My dear Sir,

If you refer to my letter of July 1921 regarding the clock in the former Methodist school and your reply to same dated July 12, 1921, you will be acquainted with the present condition.

A certain Indian here, whose name I cannot recall, has repeatedly called here claiming that the clock belonged to them. I referred them, for he always brought an interpreter, to the Indian Department stating that as soon as the order would come to me to give up the clock should do so.

In the meantime he wrote to some certain Mr. Chandler and bought me the letter which stated
that the said clock was claimed by himself and his wife. I thereupon asked him to allow me to send the letter to the Department and obtain authority to transfer the clock to him. He would not agree to this, and after saying many unpleasant things about the Department and the Government at large he demanded me to give the clock up stating that it was not the business of the Government etc. I refused to surrender the clock until I received orders, so he threatened to have me to court etc. You understand that I am not in fact alarmed by his threat, but I wish you to kindly write me an order to either give or keep the clock together with authority to purchase another to replace it, for it is one of the best.
Should we have, should you decide to hand him over the clock. There is absolutely no use in trying to reason with some of these people they will not understand.

Trusting that you may settle this little difficulty at once as possible.

Sincerely,

Sister Mary Gabriel

Dear Sir,

It has been the custom of the Department to make an allowance for prizes in the schools at the end of the year. From 1915 to 1921, the Department allowed $20.00 for each school. Last year I asked for $10.00 extra for The Continuation Class which was granted.

In view of the fact that the number of children attending school has so increased, that the price of books has not in any way lowered, it is very difficult to give rewards to the pupils as the amount allowed is insufficient. On the supposition that the Department would still allow $40.00, there should only be an average of 12 cts for each child. It is next to impossible to get a book for less than 75 cts or $1.00, and unless I go bargain hunting for a month ahead, I cannot make ends meet. I would therefore ask for further allowance leaving it to your good judgment as to how much more than $50.00 the Department could give for this purpose.

The children have put in a good year's work, I would like them to leave school happy and satisfied for nothing so influences children for renewed efforts as contentment. All of us want adequate reward for our efforts and surely children are no exception to this rule.

I will await your reply before proceeding any further with the preparations for the end of the school year.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Madam,

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the grant that will be allowed for the purchase of prizes for distribution to the pupils of the schools under your charge on the Caughnawaga Reserve before they close for the coming summer holidays.

In reply I beg to say in view of the excellent work that is being carried on by yourself and the teachers, we have decided to allow the sum of $100 for the purchase of prizes, etc. We will have a large number of demands for the same purpose from our other schools and, as our funds are limited, it will not be possible to make a larger increase in the grant allowed your schools than the above stated amount, viz: $100.

In making the purchase of these prizes, it will be necessary for you to obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, from the merchants from whom the goods are purchased. These accounts you should hand to Mr. Agent Brossard, who is being informed of the amount allowed, and he will then certify these accounts and forward to the Department in order that payment can be made.

I sincerely hope that the grant we are allowing, which is double that of last year, will solve for you the problem of obtaining suitable gifts or prizes for all the pupils deserving the same.

Your obedient servant,

Delorimier is desirous of borrowing the sum of $400.00 from the Bank, giving as security rental which is payable by this Department to him for a house in the village of Caughnawaga, used by this Department for school purposes, and in reference to the matter I beg to say that if you will have Mr. Delorimier execute a Power of Attorney, asking that this Department pay over to the Hochelaga Bank all moneys due him as rentals for the above named house, the same will be honoured by this Department, but this Department assumes no liability in the matter nor will this Department be responsible for repayment of the loan made to Delorimier by you only in so far as moneys due by this Department to the said Delorimier made up and covered by the Power of Attorney executed by him in favour of the Bank of Hochelaga.

The Power of Attorney should be forwarded to this Department, addressed to Mr. J. D. McLean, Secretary Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

The annual rental paid to Mr. Delorimier is $75.00.

Your obedient servant,

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, in which you request that 8 Harvard Adjustable Desks, of a similar type to those already in the school, be supplied for the use of the Continuation School on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to inform you that the Department is today placing an order with the W. F. Villas Company, Cowansville, Que., to ship, freight prepaid, addressed to you at Adirondack Junction, Que., the above number of desks, with cherry lids and chairs to match.

The W. F. Villas Company will send their account in duplicate to Mr. Agent Brosseau, who is being informed of the order having been placed covering these desks. My dear Sir,

I beg to call your attention to the following items to which I kindly request you to give consideration before the opening of the fall school term -

1st.- All the desks in all the schools need a coat of varnish to preserve them and keep them in good condition.

2nd.- Many desks need to be repaired, as every available seat will be occupied, and having none to spare each desk must be fit to be used. A carpenter could do this in a few days I should judge.

Some of the black boards especially in two rooms of Girls' School, one room in Boys' school and the old Methodist school need either to be repaired or renewed. A painter here assured me that with Sherwin Williams Black Board paint he could fix those up and make them last a few years longer.

The two cedar posts holding the gates of the school (formerly Methodist) are falling to pieces and need to be renewed.

5th.- The two Artesian wells, one in this last named school and the other in the Boys' school need to be cleaned. The water is absolutely filthy and unfit for use.

6th.- Some system of ventilation will have to be devised to eliminate the odor from the toilets in the Girls' School. An air pipe should be placed over the cess pool and another to draw out the impure air. The infection is absolutely harmful to the health of the teachers and pupils.

7th.- The services of a carpenter would be needed for a few days to repair locks, bolts and so many odds and ends that get out of work during a year.

These are the most pressing needs and I would kindly request that they be given attention early that the schools may be all in good working order for September 5th.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

My dear Sir,

As the schools are about to open in a few days the following articles will be needed for cleaning and keeping the classrooms in order:

3 bbls dustbane 250 lbs each
3 gallons of Cedar Oil
3 boxes Soap for use in schools
20 packages Pearline for washing floors
1 dozen boxes Gillets Lye for sinks and toilets
4 Hair Brushes for Janitor's use
4 Dusters -- sanitary
1 box Toilet Paper
1 gallon Desinfectant for toilets.

I would further request that the Janitors of each school be provided with a gasoline lantern for sweeping. School finishing at 4 p.m. especially during the short days gives little time for sweeping and the excuse offered is that there is no light. I understand it is quite impossible to sweep in the dark and after discussing the question with the Agent we considered it a necessity, as we have had any amount of trouble about the sweeping and dusting of the classrooms. The price of a gasoline lantern with a powerful light is in the neighborhood of $12.00. If you consider this purchase feasible, I will await your decision with anxiety.

Respectfully yours,

My dear Sir,

Would you kindly advise me if the Department will allow this year a sum in the sum of $35.00 for the purchase of sewing material for the Girls' School? This amount would not be sufficient in view of the fact that we have about one hundred (100) girls who follow this Course, but we have been utilizing much of the material sent by the Department of the Soldiers' Civil Re-Establishment, yet the goods sent cannot be all turned to account. We mostly need new — needles, thimbles, scissors and other such things which are so easily lost, broken or otherwise destroyed. I would, furthermore, ask if the sum previously allowed for the washing of towels, etc., in the School will be continued. This is usually Thirty-five ($35.00) Dollars.

We would request the authority to purchase about five (5) yards of oil cloth for the dining room. We will use it as runners to protect the heavy and more valuable under linoleum in places most exposed to wear.

Preparatory to the Holidays, we will need to refreshen the varnish on the floors and hallways, and I would, therefore, ask to be allowed to purchase two (2) gallons of floor varnish and wax.

My dear Sir,

Immediately upon receipt of your letter No. 6-4-5 relative to the account due Mr. Courcel amounting to $38.13 and which you claim was paid on September 29th 1922 I communicated with Mr. Courcel over the telephone and he assures me that he never received the check of which you speak. He says he received $25.50 sometime in September for an ash pan and a few incidentals. Would you be good enough to let me know who endorsed check No. 1966, as these vouchers must have been returned from the Bank of Montreal. Mr. Courcel will then be in a position to know if there was any fraud committed by his employees.

I would furthermore call your attention to an item of $31.95 freight which I paid on the first car load of coal sent by the Weaver Coal Co., October 24th. I sent the bill through the Agent with receipt attached, about one month ago. Mr. Brown assured me that the Weaver Coal Co. refunded this amount to the Department through him, but the bill has never been paid to me. I would be grateful if you looked up this matter.

I would also be thankful for an explanation regarding the payment of the September Quarter Bonus to teachers. There is $180.00 due and as I counted upon receiving this amount I paid up all my bills to date thinking this money would tide me over December. Had I foreseen such a delay, I would have left some bills standing and kept enough ready cash for every day use. A word of explanation on this subject will also be appreciated.

Sir,—
I beg to inform you that on the 12th instant, at 10 o'clock A.M. the supply of water to the Caughnawaga Girls' School has discontinued and this now a great cause of trouble to the Teachers and the children attending that school. It is supposed that the main pipe is frozen some place underground and outside of the building.

As there was absolute necessity that this question be attended at once, I have hired the services of an Indian named White, whom is recommended by Rev. Sister Superior. I am informed that the exit, or common sewer has been laid over and in contact with this main water pipe. I have ordered White to arrange for a supply of boiled water into the school basement and to let it out, if possible, in order to thaw out the main laid underneath. My dear Sir,

I have to report on the condition at the Girls' School. When the thaw began we noticed that water crept into the basement of the school, at first in small quantities, but on Friday, April 7th, the water rose to about one inch. All this week we have been fighting to keep the water down, but in spite of all efforts it rose to eight or ten inches. The evil effects of such a damp cellar on the teachers and pupils has worried me greatly, so today I took it upon myself to remedy conditions. I employed two men with a pump to clear the basement of water and another to dig a drain to the river.

Two factors combine to bring about this unusual condition:

Firstly - The road in front of the school was macadamized, made higher and no outlet left for the water to take its course; secondly - The depression between the school and the Council House which previously held the water was filled in and as a result the water comes into the cellar. The unusual cold winter may also have had its effect, but the results are altogether unpleasant.

To add to the inconvenience the cess-pool has either frozen or overflowed and the toilets in the school cannot be used.

Mr. Agent Letourneau visited the school today and approved of my action upon which he will make his report to the Department. The foundations of the school have been undermined somewhat, and well needed repairs will have to be made to prevent the repetition of this inconvenience.

I consider that the people building the road should be compelled to put in some system of drainage to allow the water to flow towards the river.

Trusting that the Departmental Engineer may soon come to Caughnawaga to settle these difficulties,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Mr. Agent Letourneau asked me for information regarding the condition of the toilets at the Continuation School about which the Inspector reported unfavorably, and by way of explanation and information I would say the following:

The Continuation Class Boys use the same toilets as the other Boys. These were built some years ago and might accommodate a class of twenty or thirty pupils. We have over two hundred boys using these toilets and it would require the services of a man every day just to keep them in order. It is impossible for the janitor who has six furnaces to heat, and seven classes to sweep besides shoveling and attending to pumps, radiators, etc. The caretaker, George Latour, is the most painstaking diligent man I ever met. Up at 5 o'clock every morning and never in bed until after 10 o'clock when he goes the rounds of the six furnaces. He sifts the ashes using the clinders, splits the wood and looks after the general welfare of the teachers. His task is a heavy one and were it not for his wife, who does the sweeping, he would never get through.

It is useless to repair these toilets, what is needed is toilets in the basement of the school that may be flushed, and in sufficient number to meet present conditions. It is impossible to run the schools here now on the plan that the Department outlined in 1910 or 1911, as conditions have absolutely changed. In connection with the Continuation Class, we put up a small toilet on the Belcourt property which is used only by the Girls. The key is kept in the classroom and it is always locked. Boys have no access there.

The Inspector must have also reported on the crowded conditions of the schools. It is next to impossible to lodge the children in the present quarters. The idea of not receiving any children under seven cannot be carried out, as the Mothers lament and wail if we refuse to accept the children. They tell me the children go to the river and they are in continual dread of the children old enough to run around, are not in school. We use all the eloquence we can to keep the children out, but the final plea is that we are accommodating and unless we yield to their entreaties the whole neighborhood is in an uproar. There is a great deal to be gained by giving all a fair chance, but we lack space, and that we cannot supply unless the Department enlarges the schools to meet conditions at present.

Trusting you will understand that these is no fault of the Janitor if conditions such as reported by Mr. Gilman exist.

MEMORANDUM.

SCHOOLS BRANCH.

As per instructions dated April 23rd, copy of which is on file 5-7-5, I have investigated the question of providing a sanitary and reliable sewage and drainage system for the boys' school on Caughnawaga Indian Reserve which was reported to be inadequate on account of the number of pupils which has increased from sixty at the time of the erection of the building, to over two hundred which is now the average attendance of this school.

The present condition of the toilets outside the building is fully described in correspondence from the Principal, dated April 10, and that from Indian Agent, dated April 23rd, on file 5-7-5, and which I find to be accurate in every respect.

After making a survey of the grounds surrounding the building, I came to the conclusion that a first class sewage disposal system could be installed for this school which would consist in the installing, in the basement of the school which is thoroughly suitable for that purpose, of four cast iron water closets for the pupils and one ordinary closet for the teachers, also four cast iron urinals. These closets and urinals would be automatically flushed with water about four times a day. The water would be pumped from the present well by a small gasoline engine to a new tank which would be installed on the ground floor of the school without any inconvenience. The sewage from the building would be treated in a small concrete septic tank in the school yard, and then discharged into a creek located in the common of the reserve, at a distance of about 270 feet from the school building.
This system would also be used for the drainage of the basement of the school which is not provided with any kind of drainage system.

The cost of the above mentioned work would be as follows:

I beg to refer to your letter of March 7th last, and to ask you whether any means are to be taken by your Department in order to prevent the frost into the water main at the Caughnawaga Girls' School, as it happened during last winter. I am informed that even if this water main is at a depth of seven feet, it will liable to freeze again during the cold months because of the permanent uncovered ground around the Catholic church where the pipe has been laid, also because this water main has been re-buried with broken stones instead of non-conductive materials. The water tanks into the cellar of the girls' school are leaking - need repairs, or to be replaced.

Ottawa, July 11th, 1923.

Sir:

Sister Mary Gabriel has forwarded a list of supplies required for the next school year for the four village schools and the St. Isidore Road school on the Caughnawaga reserve. She requested that you be given authority to purchase these supplies. I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to purchase the following, viz:

- 2 barrels Dustbane,
- 3 boxes soap,
- 2 boxes toilet paper,
- 12 Doz. brooms (corn),

- 2 whisk brooms,

- 2 radiator brushes,
- 2 large lamp shades,
- 6 lamp chimneys (long),
- 25 lbs. washing powder,
- 3 O'Cedar mops,
- 2 Gals. disinfectant.

You should consult the Sisters before making the purchase as to the kind of materials required.

Competitive prices should be obtained, and the purchase made from the firms quoting the lowest price.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded, together with an abstract of the prices received, and the names of the firms asked to quote.

When these goods arrive at Caughnawaga they should be delivered at the teachers' residence for distribution to the various schools as required.

Sir,

Please authorize me to purchase prizes for the pupils of the boys' school and for the pupils of the girls' school in the village of Caughnawaga to the amount of $10.00 each. These will be distributed at the close of the classes, on June 20, if this date is agreeable to the Department.
