General remarks.

There is reported to be at least 400 children of school age in the village who are enrolled as follows:

Boys' school—124 pupils enrolled, 48 average attendance.
Girls' school—73 " " , 45 " "
Mission school—52 " " , 11 " "

Total—348 — — — — — 104

It has already been shown in the above report that the buildings now in use for boys' and girls' school are decidedly unfit for school purposes, and entirely lacking in space to accommodate 196 pupils enrolled or even the 83 of average attendance, who are crowded into space which under the most favourable circumstances should not accommodate more than 83 pupils, also that no ventilation of any kind has been provided notwithstanding the excessive overcrowding in rooms unfit for school purposes.

This leaves at least 152 children who do not at anytime attend school, and 517 children for which no school accommodation is provided, and owing to the absence of this accommodation could not attend providing they wished to do so.

The recreation grounds is a small unfenced square used in common by boys' and girls' schools.

To provide adequate school accommodation for 75% of the 400 pupils available, in the most economical way will necessitate the erection of a combined graded school having eight class-rooms the building to be of modern type, well lighted, ventilated, and built in a central part of the village, on large grounds which should provide ample accommodation for the recreation which will assist in increasing the stamina and physique of these Indians while young in addition to their mental development.

MEMORANDUM:—

Deputy Superintendent General

Tenders were advertised for the construction of two schools buildings on the Caughnawaga reserve, which were to be received up to noon of May 8th. When the time for opening the tenders arrived it was found that no offers had been received. On the following day two tenders were sent in to the Department for the erection of these buildings. The names and addresses of the tenderers with the amounts asked is as follows:

J. B. Laflèche & Sons, Lachute, Boys' School $11350.00
" " " St. Isidore Rd. School 3225.00
Joseph Dubuc, St. Isidore, Boys' School 13000.00
" " " St. Isidore Rd. School 2500.00

ample time and publicity was given to any intending tenderers to put in their tenders and if tenders were to be called for again it would cause delay in commencing the work which should be undertaken at once so that the buildings may
be ready for occupation before the cold weather sets in.

The tender of Mr. Joseph Dubuc was not accompanied by a certified cheque as called for in the advertisement, while Messrs. Lafleur and Sons submitted a certified cheque for $1400.00. Messrs. Lafleur and Sons tender for the two schools is $925.00 lower than that of Dubuc, who furnished no security. Lafleur and Sons erected two buildings on the Caughnawaga reserve last summer in a satisfactory manner and as they are experienced and reliable contractors I would recommend that their tender for both buildings be accepted.

Chief Accountant.

Since writing the above memorandum another tender has been received - too late for consideration, and without the required security deposit. However, the amount of the tender shows that my recommendation in favor of Lafleur & Sons is in the best interests of the Department. Mr. M. J. Aquin, the tenderer to whom I refer, offers to do the work for $10,950.00, that is $4425.00 more than the tender of Messrs. Lafleur.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the two school-houses to be erected on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve in the County of Laprairie, in the Province of Quebec,

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the first ______ day of October ___________ A.D. 1911.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of fourteen thousand, five hundred and seventy-five dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

Caughnawaga, Que.

A Council Meeting held this 5th day of September, 1914, presided over by Mr. J.M. Brosseau, Asst. Indian Agent.

Resolution No. 13.

Whereas it is reported that the village school is overcrowded, there being (70) seventy pupils attending and classrooms large enough and provided for only 48, and in consequence there were 22 enrolled children dismissed owing to the lack of space, and there are as many as seventy others not attending; and whereas the compulsory regulations are in force upon this reserve and as there two class-rooms unoccupied in the upper story of the boys school building, one of these class-rooms being completely furnished with all that is necessary but the teacher.

It is therefore resolved on the motion of J.M. Jocks, seconded by Mitchel Morris that in order to comply with the requirements of the law and necessity of the children that an extra teacher be engaged without delay to instruct the children that should attend.

Adopted unanimously.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Brosseau of Caughnawaga forwarded a resolution from the Council of the band calling attention to the overcrowding of the two Roman Catholic schools in the village. Each of the class-rooms in these two schools has accommodation for 48 children.

I asked Mr. Ohene to look into this matter of overcrowding and he informed me that on the day he called at the Girls' School there were 90 children in the Junior room and 45 in the Senior room. In the Junior room the children were obliged to sit three at a desk which should accommodate two. The same state of affairs existed in the Boys' School, where there were 85 children in the Junior room and 50 in the Senior.

There is ample accommodation in both these buildings for an extra class-room. As there are many more children who should attend these schools I think it would be only right to utilize the space and engage a teacher for each.
each school temporarily until other permanent arrangements could be made.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Chene of this Department has called my attention to the fact that there are no fire escapes on the Boys' and Girls' Schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve. There are over 150 children in attendance at each of these schools and the junior classes are held above the ground floor. There is a main staircase running through the center of the building in each school and, should a fire occur, it would be a very difficult matter to get the children from the upper story safely out of the building.

It seems to me that as a safeguard fire escapes should be provided.

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6077, file 305-5, part 3)
Ottawa, December 11, 1917.

Memorandum,

Mr. Scott,

As per instructions, plans of a fire-escape have been prepared for the boys' and girls' schools, Caughnawaga, the erection of which has been approved on a memorandum submitted to your office by the Schools' Branch.

The fire-escape as prepared by the plans consists of a series of light steel stairs, the only reliable type for Kindergarten schools, such as both buildings are. These are to be placed in the rear elevation of the building and the estimated cost of the work is $455.00 for each school.

Owing to the constant increase of the price of steel, and the time required for the construction of this type of fire-escape, I would recommend that the work be started as soon as possible.

Prices for this work could be obtained from firms in Montreal and Ottawa if desired. Specifications will be prepared immediately if this should meet with your approval.

Sir,

The Department has received, through Mr. Agent Brossard, a list of repairs that are needed to be made at the Boys' and Girls' Schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve. These repairs are stated to be as follows:

1. Desks of six classes are without a speck of varnish, would need to be sandpapered and varnished.
2. Door locks broken in two classes.
3. Door leading to fire escape does not work.
4. A few desks need repairing, about four or five.
5. Porches, entrances to both schools need paint.
6. Ceiling of Girls' School (Assembly Hall) in very poor condition, would need painting or calomining.
7. The fences are rusting for want of paint.
8. Fifteen feet of Hyloplate would be needed by the 4th Class in Girls' School for blackboard space.
9. Children of 3rd and 4th classes have no place to hang clothes. A portable frame with hooks could easily be made.
10. A few chairs at residence would need new straw bottoms.

Upon the occasion of your next visit to Caughnawaga you will be good enough to look into this matter, and you are hereby authorized to see that the repairs considered by you to be necessary are made. You should see that the work required to be done is satisfactorily completed at the lowest possible price.

Hyloplate blackboards can be supplied through the government stationery office, and you will be good enough to give the exact dimensions of the board required.

You should also arrange to have the fire escapes painted at both the Boys' and Girls' Schools.

Your obedient servant,

L'ÉDUCATION DES SAUVAGES À CAUGHNAWAGA

Du correspondant de la PRESSE :

Caughnawaga, 22.—Le département des affaires sauvages continue de faire preuve de ce qui touche l'éducation des Iroquois, ses pupilles. Après leur avoir bien quelques années de cours qui peuvent soutenir honorablement la comparaison avec celles données à d'autres écoles, il y a une singularité d'égale importance et y avoir appel d'excellents entraîneurs. Dans le cas de Sainte-Anne, il vient de paraître que son ouvrage en fait une institution un magnifique système d'éducation.

L'inspecteur M. Gélinas, qui vient de visiter les établissements dans les écoles de la réserve s'est dit très satisfait de voir ce qu'il y a de plus beau. Il ne se serait pas de féliciter les maîtresses et les élèves de cette école. L'éducation des sauvages est entre les mains du gouvernement d'Ottawa. Le trésorier du département est actuellement pour fin d'éducation à Caughnawaga. Ce chiffre représente actuellement au delà de 200 enfants. Il y a en plus un délai de 60 enfants qui sont inscrits à Spanish River, Ont. Ces chiffres montrent que si la grève qui s'en va en illimité au moins celle qui s'en vient promet de ne pas être.
The Department of Indian Affairs continues to interests itself in everything that concerns the education of the Iroquois their wards. After having built them four magnificent schools which could honorably sustain comparison with those of any municipality of the same importance and after bringing excellent teachers, the Sisters of St. Anne's. It has completed its work by the installation of a magnificent aqueduct system.

The inspector Mr. Gilman who has just completed his autumn visit through the schools of the reserve has declared himself satisfied of everything he has seen and heard and warmly congratulated the mistresses and the pupils. We know that the education of the Indians is in the hands of the Federal Government.

The Federal treasury spends annually $17,000.00 for educational purposes at Caughnawaga.

The schools contain actually over 300 children. There are also more than 60 children at the industrial school of Spanish River, Ont. These figures show that if the vanishing generation is illiterate the coming one is promising not to be so.

Ottawa, August 24, 1920.

Dear Sir,

Kindly grant me an advance of $600.00 to pay for labour and materials in connection with the painting of the Girls' and Boys' and Protestant schools at Caughnawaga, Que.

Please also furnish me with a Requisition for Transportation from Ottawa to Montreal by Grand Trunk Rwy.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
My dear Sir,

I take the liberty of addressing you today to ask for authorization to purchase seventy-five or one hundred yards of roller towelling for the schools. Those in use have given almost five years of service, and many of them are completely worn out. Since the installation of a water system in the Boys' and Girls' Schools we are using double the number of roller towels, for it is so much easier to keep the children's hands clean when soap and water are available at any time. We also have to supply the Continuation School. Prices vary from cotton towelling at 24 cents a yard to linen towelling at 45 cents. I would suggest the latter as being more durable.

I would also request that the Department allow me to have bound in convenient forms for the Teachers' use the Educational Magazines, Periodicals, Reviews, and Teachers' Helps which we have been collecting for the past five years. It would be a very aid to the teachers to have matter of this kind classified and available. There are now twelve teachers including Principal and Assistants engaged in teaching in the Caughnawaga Schools, and we really do what lies in our power to help them improve their methods of teaching. I have collected and classified 34 volumes which I can have bound for about $1.10 per volume. I would allow 17 for each school.

I would furthermore request that I be authorized to purchase from Mrs. Patton a few articles of furniture which she is willing to dispose of at great sacrifice, and which will be needed in our new Residence. The Jacobs family whose house we now occupy left here many articles of furniture because they had no place to store them away. We have been using 3 cupboards, 1 side-board, four tables and over a dozen chairs besides many other articles most necessary in a house-hold. Mrs. Patton will leave nothing unless we pay for it. She has a very fine desk and chair which will be needed in the Principals School Office at the Residence, she offers both for $40.00. I have a smaller desk which I would thus be able to use in my private office.

Trusting that you will be able to grant my requests,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours Respectfully,

[Signature]

RESOLUTION NO. 91

Whereas it has been publicly discussed and submitted for the action of the Council for the Band, that the discipline and proper surveillance of the children attending the Reserve schools, when the said children are at recess and in leaving same after school hours, are deplorably lacking and discouraging, and whereas owing to such state, the death of one pupil has resulted,

Therefore it is hereby resolved that some better surveillance should be exercised over the children when at play, especially the boys, and whereas it is evident that they cannot be efficiently controlled by women, therefore it behooves that a man should be in control of the discipline over the boys.

Adopted.

Disapproved:
because I understand the council has nothing to do with the government of the governance of the schools.

RESOLUTION NO. 98

Whereas at a public meeting it was suggested that the Council for the Band should pass a resolution suggesting that the children should attend nearest school in the vicinity, irrespective of sex, and,

Whereas owing to the present conditions, children of the reserve, of tender ages, in attending school are obliged to pass school houses on the way, in all sorts of weather and hardship, and

Whereas it could be easily arranged that children of both sexes could attend the school nearest their abode, therefore,

IT IS HEREBY RESOLVED that the present system be altered to accommodate the children of either sex to attend the school nearest to which they reside.

Adopted.

St. Constant, November 6th, 1920.

Sir,

Concerning resolutions Nos. 90 and 91 I pretend that the Council has nothing to do with the management of education.

J.M. Brosseau,

St. Constant, November 30th, 1920.

I wish to draw the attention of the Department on resolution 91 more specially, and I must say that according to my personal recollections and from enquiries made, I came to the conclusion that this resolution is nothing but malicious and comes out of the head of chief P.J. Delisle, and that his colleagues did not understand anything of it. The Sister Superior affirms that in the last three years only one pupil died, that this pupil named McComber died at Lachine of Spanish Grippe.

This affirmation is corroborated by the Rev. Father Gras.

Councillor Angus Montour testifies that never to his knowledge has any pupil received any mortal wound at the School and for my part, after having been Agent at Caughnawaga for six years, it is the first time I heard of such case.

The Sisters have always appeared to me to have an absolute control over the pupils and the latter are most respectful for their teachers. When over 150 young boys playing together we can always expect them to scramble a bit, but I always noticed that those children were under the immediate supervision of one or two sisters.

Councillor Angus Montour adds that all that the Councillors meant to say in this resolution No. 91, was that the boys school should be directed by a man. After all the progress accomplished since the 1st of January 1915, when the present system was inaugurated, it would be a crime to revert to the old system. My intention is not to cast any reflection on lay teachers as I am an ex-teacher myself; but with young Indians the reverend Sisters are incomparably superior.

Yours etc., J.M. Brosseau,
Indian Agent.

Teacher's Residence,
Caughranage Jan 15/21

My dear Mr. Brossard,

I already told you that we had the greatest difficulty in getting supplies from the Department. All the month of December we were short of paper and used up every available scrap in the house. I made repeated requests for paper and pencils, so on Monday Jan 15th I sent a messenger to Pacheco to get supplies to start the children. It is quite impossible to keep 300 children in school without paper or pencils.

On Friday the 14th I received 6 boxes of lead pencils from Ottawa so I hope that the paper will soon be in. We have enough to last until Feb 1st.

The other rooms are full, as
all the children returned, and are very well disposed to work.

Trusting that this bill will go through without the formality of competitive prices, for it was quite impossible to do otherwise.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Sir,

With further reference to the placing of gongs on the two large schools, I would say that I priced them and inquired about the cost of installation. While discussing the question it was suggested that the gong be rang from the inside by means of an electric button, or in other words that an electric call bell be used. Furthermore an electric alarm bell for fire drill could be placed on the same battery. This appeals to me very strongly, and I am pleased to state that I can have a large ten inch call bell put on the outside of the building, with a small dismissal and a fire bell placed on the inside on a dry battery for $30.00 for each school. This amount covers the cost of material and installation. With this great help I think that tardiness will be a thing of the past.

I also inquired about the cost of a good time-keeper to be used as a Master Clock in each school. The "Seth Thomas" is the only dealer here are willing to recommend. A large twelve inch dial Seth Thomas wall clock would cost $18.00. The price is uniform as I have quotations from Henry Birks Co Goodwin's Limited and Murray and O'Shea.

The clock in the Continuation School was in such poor order that it could not be used, the Teacher was obliged to carry a hand clock to the school from the house every day. Towards the end of the year I had the clock removed to the Residence and we tried to get it into working order and I am pleased to say that we have succeeded. While the caretaker was carrying the clock over he was stopped by Mr. Deer who told him that the clock was not the property of the Department of Indian Affairs but belonged to the Methodist Association. Now that the clock is in good condition I would like you to tell me if we shall keep the clock or return it to the Methodist Organization. I must say that the clock is a very good one and might be worth ten or twelve dollars.

Awaiting an early reply,

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Attention of Mr. L. D. McLean
OTTAWA, July 12th, 1921.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, submitting an estimate of the cost of placing gongs on the boys' and girls' school buildings at Caughnawaga, and stating that you can have a 10" call bell installed on the outside of each building, with a small dismissal and fire bell placed on the inside on a dry battery at a cost not exceeding $30.00 for each school. In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and installation of a gong on each of these buildings. The cost and installation of same should not in each case exceed your estimate of $30.00.

Regarding a clock for each of these schools, I beg to say that you may purchase a "Seth Thomas" clock for each of the schools.

It will be necessary to obtain competitive prices for the gongs and clocks, and accounts in duplicate covering the cost of material and labour should be handed to Mr. Agent Brosseau, who should certify the same and send them to the Department for payment. The matter of installing suitable gongs and the purchase of the clocks should be done as cheaply as possible.

Regarding the clock in the Continuation School, I beg to say that you may retain this clock for the present. The Department is of the impression that it supplied this clock to a Methodist School in the first instance, but should a demand be made for the clock at a later date, the question of authorizing the purchase of another one for the Continuation School would receive consideration.

Your obedient servant

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Sister Mary Gabriel,
Principal, Caughnawaga Schools,
CAUGHNAWAGA, P.Q.

Sir:-

Replying to your letter of September 1st, with reference to the placing at a greater depth, a part of the main water pipe of the water works system at the girls' school, Caughnawaga, would you please advise me whether the portion of pipe referred to in your letter is located between the church and the school building, or if it is part of the intake pipe between the St. Lawrence River and the machinery room in the Mission Building.

I beg to add for your information that this question has been already investigated to a certain extent, and it was found that the troubles which were experienced in connection with this water supply system in the girls' school were due to the fact that the intake pipe which is in charge of the mission, was frozen, which resulted in preventing the school being furnished with any water for several weeks. As you are aware the whole of the main pipe between the church and the school building was replaced last year, and lowered to such a depth as to be considered frost proof.

I shall await your report before giving this matter any further consideration.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Fairlie,

As per instructions of May 16th, I have completed the various repairs and alterations of the Caughnawaga School, more especially to the heating system.

A quantity of materials such as paint, tools, water proofing for the repairing of the roofs, etc., have been stored in the work shop, located in the basement of the teachers' residence. In fact everything that was left unused was turned over to Mr. Latour, the caretaker.

I think it my duty to bring to your attention that when this employee was engaged, it was understood that he would attend to all repairs required at any of the school buildings in the Caughnawaga village, including the water supply and heating systems.

The new Superior should therefore be advised that in future any repairing work in connection with the above mentioned systems should be carefully looked after by Mr. Latour. It was on account of his knowledge of steam fitting work that his salary as caretaker was considerably raised at the time of his appointment.

The teachers' residence is provided with all the tools required for this kind of work, and the sisters should be made to understand that proper care of the building and their contents, by Mr. Latour, should be given precedence over all other services at the teachers' residence.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith, two blue print copies of an outside closet, to replace the present one at the boys' school, Caughnawaga.

As you will note, it is proposed that this house be built entirely of dressed lumber, studding to be 2 x 4, with cleaboard sheeting on the outside. The roof may be covered either with stained cedar shingles or three ply ready roofing. The floor should be 5" thick, built of cement and covered with three coats of cement waterproofing, which is already stored at the teachers' residence.

The boxes underneath the seats are to be lined inside with galvanized iron, no. 24 gauge, and installed on wood rollers in order to facilitate their removing. There should be one box for each compartment. Provision to be made for the installing of a small floor drain, 3" diameter, in each of the two rooms, with galvanized iron gratings. The floor to be graded in such manner as to have a slant towards these openings. It is desired that the urinal stalls be lined with either aluminum or lead sheeting, to a height of about three feet from the floor, which will have a semi-circular shape of the width shown on plan.

The drainage outlets at the end of the trough are to be connected together to a 4" vitrified drain pipe, and continued into a small cess pool, which might be installed in the most suitable place in the rear of this building.

Ventilators 10" square are to be placed on the roof above each of the two rooms.
The Department will rely on you to see that this work is performed in the most satisfactory and economical manner by day labour.

If you have any suggestions to make which would improve the above mentioned description, I shall be glad to have them before you proceed with the work.

It is desired that competitive prices be obtained in the purchasing of all materials required for this work.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Liburneau showed me the letter you wrote him on Oct. 9, in which you state that you cannot give my account any consideration because I did not get the required authorization from the Department. On reading the contract I saw that the Department was responsible for the cost.
of the maintenance of the water works system. I thought it the most natural thing in the world to have the work done and then ask you to pay the cost! I never thought that you preferred to send a man from Ottawa to supervise such simple work as the sinking of a pipe.

If you have time to bear the cost of that work just think how long it will take me to pay it with my salary of 27 cents a day!

Dear Sir,

Dear Sir,

For the last two weeks the toilets at the Girls' School have not been in good working order. The janitor has had much trouble on account of a frequent overflow of water. Monday morning, the school was so infected that I took it upon myself to send immediately for a plumber. He located the trouble and everything is in good condition now.

The outside toilets at the Boys' School are nearly completed. If the work had not been stopped and the plan changed the building would be finished.

Mr. Chene was expected here this week, I am quite anxious to meet him.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, reporting on the condition of the toilets at the girls' school on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

With reference to these toilets, I have to request that you will see that the pupils do not interfere with the same by throwing in all kinds of articles, as was the case upon previous occasions when these closets became blocked. Close supervision should be kept by the staff of the school and very definite instructions given to the pupils regarding the throwing in of any articles or other material which would block the proper flushing of the toilets. If further trouble develops, the Department will have no recourse but to authorize the discontinuance of these inside toilets and the use only of the outside buildings.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

After the terrible storm of last Wednesday, it was impossible to get to the Schools without having the path made. St. Ann's School and Delormier School were snowed in; the front door was out of sight, the drift being so high. Hoping that you will approve of my doing so as to keep the Schools open.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to general conditions at the Caughnawaga Indian Schools. The Department is pleased to note that splendid progress is being made.

I have noted that the walls in some classrooms of the Boys' School need repairing. Please ascertain the amount of plastering required and submit it for the Department's attention in June, so that the work can be undertaken during the summer holidays. I regret that nothing can be done to improve conditions at the Delormier school, until such time as a new building and better accommodation is provided.

There are no funds available for any comprehensive activity in connection with the play grounds at both Boys' and Girls' Schools. Your recommendation that certain facilities for play be provided is receiving favourable consideration. Please have a carpenter estimate the amount and cost of materials and the labour required to purchase and erect by day labour one swing with three seats and two basketball standards at each of the Boys' and Girls' Schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that on the 11th ultimo I have visited each class of the Boys' and the Girls' School of the Caughnawaga Indian Village. The attendance was very good in spite of the cold weather and the bad roads. I am always surprised at the work accomplished in the schools here. The pupils are neat and have good behavior in general. Many of the more advanced pupils are very refined, it shows the refining influence of the Sisters who are doing excellent work in the Caughnawaga Indian Schools. I saw the semi-annual report of examinations, and Reverend Sister Superior has a right to be proud of the fine success obtained.

The walls in some of the classes in the Boys' School would need to be repaired.

Delormier School would need to be attended to. There is water constantly in the cellar, therefore, making it a very unhealthy room both for the Teacher and the pupils. The room contained 35 pupils when I visited it, and there is no means of ventilating the room during class because the pupils are seated in the windows. The room is not at all hygienic. Better accommodations should be provided. The size of the room is about 17'x 22'x 7'6".

The playground at the Boys' School would need to be filled, and the fence around should be repaired. The playground at the Girls' School would also need to be levelled. I would strongly recommend amusements, such

such as swings etc., to be placed on the playgrounds of both the Girls' and the Boys' Schools, with a number of trees to beautify the grounds. I would like to see something done this year and every year until the grounds are put into some decent kind of shape. I believe it a shame to leave the surroundings of the schools so bare and crude. In fact, I think that nothing has ever been done since the buildings were erected during the years of 1910 and 1911.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to draw your attention to the following conditions of the Caughnawaga Indian Day school buildings and surroundings that need to be attended to in a near future:

**BOYS SCHOOL**

1o - Playgrounds are in a bad condition, all holes, and always muddy; 3 or 4 carloads of cinders are necessary to fill in.

2o - Fence must be repaired on one side, the other side is all broken, cannot be repaired, length of grounds 180 feet.

3o - Water in cellar, damaged the cases of books; a few inches of cement and one coating of waterproof is recommended.

4o - Acheck valve for the pump.

5o - I would suggest that a sufficient space to put away the storm windows would be petitioned off in the cellar. The windows are piled one on top of the other without protection, consequently, many panes of glass need to be repaired in the Fall. About 300 sq. feet of 1" board would be required.

6o - Very little patching to be done on the walls (Re: Dept.File No. 5-2-5 dated April 7, 1924)

7o - Blackboards need a coat of liquid slating. Two need to be replaced. 2 gall. of liquid required. Size ones required are 10 x 3 feet.

8o - A few new curtains, several to be repaired.

9o - 3 benches, about 7 feet long each, recommended for the youngest during the recess.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
GIRLS' SCHOOL.

$70.00 1p - Grounds need to be filled in with about two carloads of cinders.

$6.00 3o - The large gate is broken, fence in pretty good condition.

$6.50 5o - Outside closets need a little repairing and screen approaches.

$89.00 4o - Ceiling in the upper rooms to be plastered; a size of 30 x 15 feet. A few patches in walls.

$5.00 5o - Blackboards need a coat of liquid slating. Two should be renewed, size: 10 x 5 feet each. 2 gall. of liquid required.

$6.00 6o - New curtains, a few to be repaired.

$7.00 7o - There are no closets to put the brooms and articles for cleaning, therefore I find a small closet behind the door of the wardrobes, down stairs, would be very necessary (7 ft. high x 4 ft. x 1 ft. deep), 100 feet of 1f board is required.

$6.00 6o - 2 benches, about 10 feet long each, for the youngsters during the recess, on the playground.

Delorimier School.

Dimension of the class room: 21 x 16 x 7 1/3 feet; 42 pupils.

There has been about 7 inches of water in the cellar for several weeks. It is too bad that something cannot be done to better such unhealthy conditions.

The health of the teachers and pupils are being greatly injured by colds and rheumatism. If I judge from a few words Sister Superior of the Caughnawaga Schools said, I think the Reverend Mother of the Order will not allow a Sister to teach there next year.

The cottage almost opposite the Teacher's Residence is vacant and I believe it would just be suitable for two classes. The house and grounds could be rented for $125 per annum. The grounds are large enough to be used for school and as the land extends right opposite the Boys' School, a piece or section of land could be used for the girls of the Continuation School who have no playground. They spend their recess sitting on the steps, because naturally they are not going to mix in with the boys, so they are deprived of exercise, which is very necessary and most healthy.

Kind Sir,

I beg to remind you that the closing of the school year is near, consequently I would be grateful for the grant of One Hundred Ten (110) Dollars such as last year for the purchase of premiums for the pupils of the Caughnawaga and Saint Isidore Road Schools. Because of the extra work which the end of the school term entails, I would like to be authorized to make this outlay as soon as convenient.

Permit me also to allude to your generous offer of a gold piece to the pupils of the Second Year Commercial on the occasion of your last visit. As there are four girls only I feel like soliciting a scholarship for one, because unlike the boys, they are handicapped in not being given the advantages of higher education. You are aware that these girls deserve prizes and rewards for their sustained effort and application in school work and I would like both parents and children to be pleased and satisfied at the Closing Exercises.

We have had an official visitation by the higher authorities of our Order and Reverend Mother Mary Leopoldine, Superior General, whom you met last year, has requested me to ask for an increase of salary for some of our teachers. I know you will think it reasonable because you acknowledge our unstinted labors and painstaking devotedness for our Indian charges, which same is attested by the different Government Inspectors and visitors in their glowing School Reports. Some of the religious teachers, who have crowded classrooms are certainly underpaid while Miss Martin and Miss Regis have a scanty number and receive larger salaries. And may I ask why could not the Sisters of the Girls' School draw the same salary as those in charge of like Standards in the Boys' School?

Asking you to consider kindly my request while thanking you for your great interest in our welfare,

I am, dear Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Sr. Mary Cecilia

August 19, 1924.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I understand that Mr. Chene is to proceed to Caughnawaga on duty, and, as no provision has been made for the special classes that were held in the Delormier building, I feel that a decision is timely concerning the question of temporary accommodation.

The Department has received a release from John O. Delormier in connection with the leasing of the property in which he has a joint share with Mrs. Annie K. Delormier. On March 27th, last, Mrs. Delormier was given notice of the Department's intention to lease the property for one year, commencing June first, 1924. She has been paid rental to December 31st, next. Mr. Indian Agent Letourneau, at our request, has written her for a release from paying any further rental. We gave up our use of the property on June 30, last.

In view of the difficulties in connection with this estate and the unsatisfactory sanitary conditions of the Delormier house (which causes the Department to look for another building for the two classes), I wish to recommend that Mr. Chene make arrangements with Mr. C. W. Cloud, owner of a building opposite the teacher's residence, for one year's rental. He has signified willingness to rent for $150 per annum.

Mr. Letourneau estimates the alterations and decorating to the Cloud property at $500, but I believe that the work can be done for less. I also recommend that Mr. Chene receive your authority to undertake the alterations and decorating that are necessary for our purposes.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

It gives me pleasure to tell you that our schools opened with a large number of pupils. About four hundred (400) have registered. All are in the best of humor and are doing wonderfully well for the time. The children are taken up with their new LaSalle Reader; it is not surprising, it is so clear and well illustrated. They are showing the greatest interest in their work and the attendance is remarkable. What a difference with the spirit of last year!

I am enclosing a copy of the report given in this morning by Mr. Jocks.

Our four graduates are most happy in their new convent home. The higher education given to our boys and girls is a great incentive, and many are desirous of obtaining a college or convent education. I think this is the beginning of a new era in Caughnawaga.

Would you be good enough to let me know if the Department would allow about fifteen dollars more for sewing material for the girls, making it sixty-five dollars ($65.00). Over one hundred girls are taught sewing, and needles, thimbles, scissors are easily lost or destroyed. The girls have no idea of economy, so our sewing classes are beginning by a course of mending, especially stockings; then they will receive lessons in plain sewing which I think is most practical. If my plans are not disturbed we shall have an exhibition of needlework at the end of the scholastic year.

I would furthermore ask if the same amount ($35.00) will be granted this year for the washing of the towels for the schools.

The repairs of the new school are almost finished and we owe you many thanks for your co-operation in obtaining a more sanitary school.

Assuring you of our appreciation for the interest you take in our Indian charges, I beg to remain, dear Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,-

Now, here is a different proposition that does not require money from the tribal funds. I intend to dig a well to have good clear water. It costs $4.00 a foot. I suppose that we would get excellent water at between 50 and 70 feet. If you will pay $300.00, I guarantee the rest of the cost, putting in of the pipes etc. The water is very bad for two or three months in the spring and after heavy rains. Besides, the ground that we put on our intake pipe is washed away every spring; even though we lowered it last year I am afraid it will freeze this year. I am sorry I made that expense, I do not intend to put any more money on that pipe. I hate to ask you to spend some more money, when you just bought us a new engine, but then, it would be too bad if we had to haul water 2 or 3 months next winter and pay for that.

O. Lecouture.

I have been anxiously awaiting your return to explain to you the impossibility of having the sweeping done in the classrooms if we have not the articles necessary for cleaning purposes.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

I wish to report on my recent visit to the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School. I made a special study of the question of accommodation that is needed for this activity. At present, classes are conducted in four buildings: 1. the Girls' School; 2. the Boys' School; 3. the former Protestant School; 4. the building we are renting. As we hope to release the third mentioned building for a Protestant Day School next year and as the rented building is wholly unsuitable, I gave first attention to the best use of the accommodation in the two brick buildings, the Boys' and the Girls' Schools. Four classes can be accommodated in the Girls' building if the roof is raised. The rooms on the second floor of the Boys' School are not suitable for classroom purposes and can be used for typewriting and domestic science. The classrooms on the first floor are quite suitable. The two old buildings, therefore, look after six classes, but ten classrooms are required, as follows:

This means, of course, coeducation practically throughout the whole school. It is true that there are two classrooms for each of the three first grades; but my suggestion to the Sister Superior was that they have boys and girls in each and divide the reserve so that the little children would be studying in the closest buildings.

The Sister Superior has lately written that she believes a still further classroom is necessary, due to the large increase expected in the continuation group for the academic year 1927-28. I have answered her letter, pointing out that it might be possible to organize the work so that the extra room would not be needed.

In addition to the ten classrooms, a domestic science room and a typewriting room, the school should have an auditorium. As four classrooms and an auditorium are required in the new building, this suggested to Mr. Chene a two storey building with four classrooms on one floor and an auditorium on the other. A small room might be set off as an office. When it is known exactly what accommodation is really necessary, I shall prepare another memorandum. The September enrolment and average attendance of 322 and 311, respectively, indicates that ten classrooms is the minimum accommodation required.

Sir,

Your visit was so short that I had no time to give you any details which would have been useful before starting the plans of your new school.

I am satisfied that each class room will be large enough to add a few weeks above the number given by Mr. Ferrier. As I told you, it will be necessary to have a meeting hall for the pupils in the basement when bad weather will not permit them to go out, also a hall or perhaps the same one could be used by those bringing their lunch; there are about 25 of them.

A toilet room for the ladies and several other rooms for the pupils: boys and girls.

Mr. Ferrier was stating that one stall for each pupil would be sufficient. This is impossible, as they are out only 10 minutes; so that for all classes it is necessary to have 4 stalls each otherwise they would have to be out one hour.

An office for myself, downstairs, near the main entrance, for parents to come and discuss their particular cases, is very much needed.

At present, I am located in a passage where all the children have to go through, and this is neither convenient nor agreeable.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Department has agreed to install an electric lighting system in both the boys' and girls' schools at Caughnawaga to replace the present system of coal oil and gasoline lamps. I am advised that the work can be performed economically by a local Indian who has been recommended by the Principal of the Schools. I should be glad, therefore, to obtain from this electrician a list of the materials required including the fixtures, a separate list being submitted for each building. The fixtures should be drop light fixtures of a modest type. You should also obtain from him the price which will have to be paid for the labour in connection with this work, should it be awarded to him by contract or day labour.

As you are aware the Department is contemplating installing a small pneumatic water supply system for each of the above schools. Before any decision can be taken as to the type of pump required, I would like to know the depth of the water well.

Your obedient servant,

Jo De McLean,
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

Le Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

I have your letter of the 16th instant, requesting that the walls which were recently replastered in the Caughnawaga schools be given two coats of paint in order to have them uniform in colour with the surrounding portions of the walls.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have these walls given two coats of paint over the recent repairs to match the present colour of the walls. With regard to Doctor Scott's instructions for the installation of a domestic water supply system at the teachers' residence and the girls' school, and the wiring of the boys' and girls' schools at Caughnawaga, I beg to say that Indian Agent Letourneau was requested on the 15th instant in letter on file 5-1-5 to obtain the required information to enable the Department to purchase the necessary material and machinery for the above mentioned work. Up to the present no reply has been received to this letter, and I consider it, therefore, impossible to proceed with the wiring of the buildings during the Christmas holidays, and I would suggest that the above mentioned installations be postponed until next month when I return to the office.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.
MONTREAL, December 28th 1926

Mr. Lorenzo Letourneau,
Indian Agent,
St.-Constant, Qué.

Dear Sir;---

We are pleased to submit you the following quotations for the electrical installation in the schools of Caughnawaga.

Although the upper rooms differ in the two schools the same number of lights and switches are required. Thirty-three lights and eighteen switches in each school having four class rooms, four wardrobes, two corridors, four entries, two stairways, front porch, cellar and store room for books.

We shall be glad to take the contract for $396.30 each school, all includes, with the best materials, concealed work, white opal shades special for schools, and drop chain as the difference in cost is but a trifle.

According to the inspectors of the Canadian Fire Underwriters, we are not allowed to use a drop cord in school rooms or public halls.

If you can favor us with an early reply, we can wire both buildings before the opening of school in January.

Trusting that these quotations will meet with your approval, we beg to remain dear Sir, with the greetings of the season,

Yours very truly,

CLOVIS ELECTRIC CO., LTD.

JNC+GL
Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant regarding the proposed installation of an electric lighting system in both the boys' and Girls' schools at Caughnawaga.

In reply I beg to say that according to your instructions I have had the opportunity to locate a reliable electrician from whom we can be assured of a satisfactory installation, by contract, in both schools.

I am enclosing herewith the price submitted by Clovis Electric Coy., Limited, Montreal, which is $396.30 for each of both boys' and girls' schools.

I believe that this is a very reasonable price and beg to recommend that this offer be approved by the Department.

It is only after having been assured that the local Indian referred to in your letter could not very well undertake this work that I took upon myself to immediately look after a responsible and experienced electrician who can (with enclosure) performed this work with a sufficient number of employees during the present school vacation, providing that this proposition meets with your immediate approval.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith copy of an agreement made between the Department of Indian Affairs and the Missionary at Caughnawaga in the month of September 1919, permitting this Department to connect the water supply system of the girls' school to that of the Mission building. By referring to Article 7 you will note that the contract is to be in force during a period of 25 years. As you are aware the supply pipe from the Presbytery is often frozen and the Department has been compelled for this reason to provide water by some other means for this school. I would ask you, therefore, to interview the Missionary, at your convenience, to find out whether he would consent to cancelling this agreement next September. The Department would then be in a position to consider the installation of a small pneumatic water supply system, which would be more economical than the present arrangements.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, April 21, 1927.

My dear Sir:

The prospect of a new school building for the next academic term has brought great joy to all. Rumors to that effect have circulated in the village and most of the people are rejoicing.

Owing to the change of site of the new building, our plans and suggestions for same cannot be carried out. Necessarily you need a clear conception of the requirements of the school before the sketch is made, so will you please allow me to submit an outline for your approbation. It is understood that it will be co-education throughout the schools.

1st. The Boys' School can accommodate the children of the First, Second and Third Grades, who live at the east end of the village. The extra classroom can be used for a lunch-room and a recreation room for the children on stormy days.

2nd. The Girls' School, if the roof is raised, can be used exclusively for the Continuation School --- Standard 7th & 8th - another class preparatory to the Quebec Academic Diploma -- a typewriting room - and a domestic-science room.

3rd. Six classrooms would be required in the new building for First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Grades -- besides the other rooms already mentioned on your first memorandum.

4th. I would suggest that the lease for the rented house across the road, which ends in August, be discontinued. Even though the new school building would not be finished for September we could organize matters to save expense of renting a house for a short period of time.

With deepest thanks for your great interest and cooperation in our Indian charges, I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Sister Mary Rose Almo
Principal.

Mr. Russell Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, informing the Department of the repairs that will be required to the various school buildings in the Village of Caughnawaga.

In reply I beg to say that you may purchase the door knobs, panes of glass and valves for radiators, and you should arrange with the janitor to perform the necessary work in having them installed. You may also purchase the paint required and arrange to have the verandah and railing of the teachers' residence painted during the coming summer. We note that about 4 gallons of paint will be required for this purpose. You may also purchase and have delivered the 300' of lumber required to repair the stable, and arrange to have the repairs to this building and also the painting of the verandah and railing of the teachers' residence carried out.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering all of the above authorized expenditures.

Relative to the repairs to the fence in front of the boys' school, I beg to say that any repairs required can stand over, as it is likely there will be other fencing required in connection with the lots on which the Department intends to erect the new school building this coming summer.

Relative to the repairs required to the roof of the teachers' residence and to the plaster in several rooms, I beg to say that you should draw this matter to the attention of Mr. Chene on the occasion of his next visit to Caughnawaga.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to ask you whether the Department has finally decided the question as to the advisibility to have a second story placed up on the Girls' school building into the Village of Caughnawaga.

In this connection, I beg to refer to your letter dated the 22nd December last - Dept-File No. 5-1-5 - by which I had been authorized to have the walls which were replastered to be given two coats of paint over the recent repairs. This work was to be performed at an approximate cost of $135.00 has not yet been done.

In case that the proposed construction of a second story would be carried out by the Department, it would therefore be advisable to have the closing exercises of the schools for the coming summer holidays to take place on or about the 17th of June. These exercises would then take place in a rather private way. The only distribution of prizes that would be required for the graduates would approximately cost $20.00, instead of a sum of $105.00 as the previous year, making a total saving of $85.00.

Furthermore, I am informed that a few of the Reverend Sisters presently teaching at the various schools of Caughnawaga are just preparing their examination for a Higher Grade, which is to take place on the 18th and the 20th of June next.

For these reasons, I beg to recommend that the closing exercises will take place on the 17th of June.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Ferrier,

I have just had an interview with the Superior of the Caughnawaga Schools concerning the proposed erection of the Central School on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, and beg to say that the plans which were prepared to meet the requirements of the building of the type and dimensions to provide the necessary accommodation will cost about $42,000.00.

The drawings as prepared provide for an assembly hall with a stage, etc., which, owing to its construction, cannot be turned into class rooms in the future.

I would like to be advised whether the sewage system is to be included in the contract for this building or if separate prices are to be invited at a later date.

[Signature]

Departmental Engineer.
Dear Sir:

I understand that you are about to build a new school for the boys at Maghnawaga. Without wishing in any way to intrude in your plans, let me suggest that at least one extra class is needed. Sister May Rita, with 51 registered, and 46 present, has too large a number for efficient work.

The Protestant Separate School is in existence and I think, to say so, in all justice and charity, cleaner and more ample quarters should be provided.

Your humble servant,

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Scott,

Tenders were receivable at noon of the 20th instant, for the construction of the new Central School at Caughnawaga, and the following tenders, made on the regular forms in accordance with the requirements of the advertisement, were submitted. The tenders contained two separate prices, one for the complete erection of the proposed building, and the second one provided for the finishing of the ground floor only, where the class rooms are located, the basement and the first floor to be completed on the outside only, as described in detail in the specification.

| Name of Contractor | Price for Complete building | Alternative Price |
|--------------------|-----------------------------|-------------------|
| Bremner Norris & Co., Montreal | $56,594.00 | $50,349.00 |
| Durand & Durand, Montreal | $56,500.00 | $43,700.00 |
| Newton Construction Co., Sherbrooke | $52,300.00 | $46,799.00 |
| LaFlamme & LaFlamme, Shawinigan Falls | $48,600.00 | $43,500.00 |
| A. LaCroix, St. Lambert | $48,555.00 | $42,635.00 |
| MacKenzie & Genest, Hull | $44,847.00 | No alternative price |

The cost of the building was estimated to amount to $42,000.00. Should funds not be available to award a contract to the lowest tenderer, I would suggest that the contractors be requested to submit a new tender for the construction and completion of the first two stories only, with a temporary flat roof. The third story which provides for an assembly hall only could be erected next year or later, and the material forming the temporary roof could be used again in the construction of the permanent gable roof. If you approve of this suggestion special forms of tender could be sent for the purpose and revised prices obtained in the course of six to ten days. This arrangement will, in my opinion, bring the expenditure close to the amount appropriated for this building.

I may add that it should be taken into consideration that the water and sewerage system will be installed this year. The source of supply for the water system will be from an artesian well, and will probably cost in the neighborhood of $400.00, whereas the sewerage system will be quite expensive. It will consist of a vitrified sewer pipe line extending from the building to the St. Lawrence river and the system...
will be costly on account of the nature of the ground, which is solid rock. This work can be performed later in the season either by day labour, employing Indians or by contract.

As already mentioned a building of smaller dimensions than that under consideration will not meet the requirements of the increased attendance at the schools on this reserve.

Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of the 12th instant relative to voucher 1144 dated 23rd ultimo and to say that after having carefully reexamined the account submitted by the Rev. Sister Superior I am under the impression that the amount of $125.15 as previously submitted was correct.

I beg to explain that the first account of $44.25 contained an item under date of April 5th, viz "Trip to St-Isidore Road School - $1.50". This charge was made for the driver, whom had been paid that sum of $1.50. While into the second account, at the same date of April 5th, a charge of a similar amount was made by the Rev. Sister Superior as "Visitation St-Isidore Road School", which amount is her own usual fee granted by the Department in this connection.

The same thing happen under date of the 22nd May in the second account. The railway express charge shows .80¢, while the account submitted is $1.30 because this difference of .50¢ was to pay the transportation of this article from the railway station to the teachers' residence.

Wiremold Conduit is installed exactly like pipe, except that a simple, patented "slip joint" is used for coupling lengths and for coupling with fittings, rather than the threaded coupling required for pipe.

Wiremold Conduit is furnished with one coupling with each length, as shown in Fig. 1.

To connect lengths of Wiremold Conduit, first push the coupling part way out of the end of Wiremold Conduit and fasten the coupling to the ceiling or wall as shown in Fig. 2.

Slip the next length of Wiremold Conduit over the edges of coupling, as shown in Fig. 3, below, thus providing a concealed coupling and firm support for Wiremold Conduit at the end of lengths.

Wiremold Conduit is now being produced with its curled edges extended, to grip firmly the tongues of Wiremold Fittings and to make this same simple, "slip joint" connection.

WIREMOLD ENAMEL

The enamel used in finishing the top of Wiremold Conduit and the covers of all its fittings is unusually tough and will withstand all ordinary handling, including bending, without chipping or peeling off.

There are, however, occasional jobs where it is advisable to retouch tool marks and other minor abrasions or to finish the bases of snap switches and similar fittings to match the buff color of Wiremold Conduit.

Half pint cans of the same high grade buff colored enamel used for the finishing of Wiremold Conduit, but of the proper consistency to be brushed on, have therefore been added to the line for the convenience of users.

Brushes are not furnished with these cans but the use of a brush about an inch wide is recommended for best results.

The work at the new Central School is now progressing rapidly and in view of the depth of the boiler room in the basement the drainage system will have to be given immediate attention. Owing to the nature of the ground, which is solid rock, and the lack of ditches in the neighborhood of the school lot, it will be necessary to construct a sewer line from the building as far as the St. Lawrence River, a distance of about 575 feet. The proposed sewerage system would consist in the laying of six inch vitrified drain pipe with an outlet in a cess pool, built of dry masonry, close to the embankment on the shore of the St. Lawrence River, similar to that already in operation for the hospital and the girls' school. As the excavation will be mostly done in solid rock, the cost of the work will amount to about $3,500.00. I beg, therefore, to recommend that authorization be given to obtain prices from the contractors in order that the completion of the basement will not be delayed owing to the lack of proper drainage.

Memorandum: The Minister's Office.

The choice of the roofing for the new Central School at Caughnawaga was left as usual to the discretion of the officer who had charge of the preparation of the plans and specifications. To improve the appearance of the building he considered it advisable to choose a type of asbestos shingle of various colours with a rough edge to imitate slate roofing. These shingles are more expensive than those of a uniform colour, which, however, would not give the same results as the colour blend type. However, as mentioned in a previous memorandum regarding this matter the Department does not wish to favour any particular manufacturer and any make of shingle which will comply with the requirements of the specifications will be accepted.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
With reference to the contents of the accompanying memorandum from the Minister's office, I beg to say that there should be no objection to permitting the use of 6"x16"x2" asbestos shingle, instead of the 9"x16"x2", which are the dimensions specified for the roofing of the Caughnawaga Central School, Que., providing that the type, texture, and appearance of the asbestos shingles as offered by the Asbestos Manufacturing Company, Ltd., are identical with those specified, that is, of different shades and with rough edges to imitate ordinary slate shingles, in order to give this roof the desired appearance as originally planned by the Department.

I cannot in this case recommend any change in the type of asbestos shingle for this roof, owing to its shape and construction. A shingle of a uniform colour will not produce the desired effect. I shall, however, in future be glad to specify the materials as fabricated by the Asbestos Manufacturing Co., Ltd., as often and whenever possible.

As this size of 9" by 16" is manufactured by the one firm in Canada, Johns-Manville Co. Limited, my firm Asbestos Manufacturing Co. Limited, is barred the job.

What we make is Indian Red 8" by 16" 1/4" thick shingles, which is considered a more suitable article for our climate, in this that it resists better to the frost than the larger shingles.

Would you kindly get me the authorization from the Department of Indian Affairs for the contractor to use my shingles 8" by 16" instead of 9" by 16".

Will you kindly let me know if this can be arranged so that this Company will have an opportunity of selling their shingles to the successful contractor.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary."

With reference to your memorandum of the 22nd ultimo concerning the type of asbestos shingles specified for the roofing of the Caughnawaga Central School, now being erected by this Department at Caughnawaga, Que., I beg to quote hereunder the item of the specification relating to this part of the building, Article 17-specifications page 42.

"Asbestos Shingles.—The roofing to be made of asbestos shingles colour blend of various colours, laid horizontally and exposed 8" x 9" to the weather and composed of 60% conglomerate brown, 20% of natural grey and 20% Indian red, laid according to the methods and instructions furnished by the manufacturers. The shingles to be nailed to the wooden roof with copper storm and galvanized iron nails, two pounds per square at the minimum. The weight per hundred shingles shall be not less than 320 lbs."

The choice of the roofing for this School was left as usual to the discretion of the officer who had charge of the preparation of the plans and specifications. To improve the appearance of the building he considered it advisable to choose a type of asbestos shingle of various colours with a rough edge to imitate slate roofing. Shingles of uniform colour would not give the same results as the Colour-Blend.

With regard to size—There should be no objection to permitting the use of 8" x 16" x ¼" asbestos shingle, instead of the 9" x 18" x ¼" which are the dimensions specified for the roofing of the Caughnawaga Central School, providing that the type, texture and appearance of the asbestos shingles as offered by the Asbestos Manufacturing Company Limited are identical with those specified, that is, of different shades and with rough edges to imitate ordinary slate shingles, in order to give this roof the desired appearance as originally planned by the Department.

I cannot, however, recommend any change in the type of asbestos shingle for the roof of the Caughnawaga Central School, owing to its shape and construction.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General

Gentlemen:

We are attaching hereto your inquiry for deep well water plant required for the new Central School at Caughnawaga Indian Village.

Our deep well home water plant, completely automatic, with 70 gallon fully galvanized tank, and 3/4 HP single phase, 110 volt, 60 cycle motor, is fully illustrated and described on page 12, of bulletin H2680, which you have in your possession. The motor is housed in a protected well ventilated frame; double pole automatic control switch; air compressor attachment driven from the cross head of the pump; base acts as an oil reservoir so that all working parts are oiled automatically when the pump is in operation; fresh water feature supplied and the pump is capable of giving you the minimum capacity of 60 gallons per hour. The motor is vertical, ball bearing, coupled flexibly to the worm shaft. The worm runs in roller bearings, the lower bearings taking the entire thrust, no thrust being taken by the bearings of the motor. Worm and worm shaft are machined from a single piece of alloy steel and a phosphor bronze worm gear is securely bolted to a flange which is forged as an integral part of the crankshaft.

We had one of our engineers in Montreal go out to the school and look over the proposition. He reports that the building is not yet up and our price given in the tender is for installation if the plumbing is brought to the basement. This does not include taking the wires from outside to the basement or fitting the outlet of the tank to the plumbing any further than the cellar, but does include the installation of the cylinders, pump rod, connections between the pump and the tank, and connections from the tank to the plumbing as stated above. Memorandum.

Dr. Scott,

When the contract for the erection of the new school at Caughnawaga was let some time ago, a Mr. Moses Guerin was appointed Inspector on the recommendation of the local Member. It was thought at that time that with inspections at intervals, the work might be properly looked after and the necessity of advertising the position obviated. Experience, however, proved that Mr. Guerin was not altogether competent and as a result it was decided to ask the Civil Service Commission to make an appointment. They advertised the position and as a result a Mr. Bersailou of Laprairie was appointed. He has advised the Agent that he is unable to accept the appointment. The work is well advanced. The roof will be on the building by the end of this week and I think, in view of the fact that the qualifications of the other applicants were very doubtful, it would be better to arrange to have Mr. Chene make weekly inspections from this time out. Mr. Letourneau is quite willing to visit the work and report progress. This, with a thorough inspection by Mr. Chene, should be quite satisfactory in view of the progress that has been made up to date as indicated above.

Last July I was advised by Miss Dumont of the Gaughnawaga Hospital that a well boring apparatus was available on the reserve and that an artesian well had just been completed at the hospital at a price of $2.00 per foot for the first hundred feet and $4.00 per foot for the remaining depth plus an allowance of fifty cents per foot for the board of the men. With your approval on June 18th instructions were given to Mr. O. Fortin, the well contractor, by the Inspector of Works to proceed with the boring of the well at the new Central School at Gaughnawaga, on the same terms as those paid to him at the Hospital. The contractor went ahead with the work and submitted an account for a well 150 feet deep, at $4.50 per foot, explaining that the amount paid by Miss Dumont at the rate mentioned above was for the enlarging or reboaring of an old well, and the deepening of it, and that the current price charged by him for the boring of a six inch artesian well in rock was $4.00 per foot for the entire depth plus an allowance of fifty cents per foot for the boarding of his men. Up to date I have refused to certify to his account, which amounts to $711.00 for the reason that the contractor proceeded with the work without the Department's authority as to the change in the terms of payment, namely from $2.00 to $4.00, and he was advised accordingly by letter of the 13th of August last.

The Department was requested on 15th of Sept. by the law firm of Perron, Taschereau, Vallee, Genest & Perron, of Montreal to reconsider the payment of this account, and I have ascertained that the price asked for by Mr. Fortin is regular and that he would be entitled to the $4.50 per lineal foot for the entire depth of the well, this being the price paid throughout the locality for this kind of work.

Before going any further with the matter, I would like to know whether his account may be given consideration or if negotiations should be entered into with his lawyers, as mentioned in the accompanying letter.

Sir,

I have received a letter from the Department about the school and Teachers' residence being entered by persons unknown.

I wish to state that one night about a month ago (while the electricians were still working at the Girls School) I was notified by an Indian that there was a light at the School; this was about two o'clock in the morning so I went immediately to the Girls School and I saw the lights in the Second class. I tried all the doors to see where I could get in to investigate as I did not have time to go to the Teachers to get the key owing to the lateness of the night. I tried the cellar door, all the doors on the ground floor were locked. I went up the fire escape and tried the door there and found the door also locked. I came down the fire escape and I tried the windows on the class that connect with the fire escape there. I found the window unlocked. I went in and looked all over down to the basement and upstairs, there was nothing suspicious or anything out of the way. Only thing I found that I could not turn the switch off to the Second Class lights? I had to take the main switch off before I was able to put the lights off. I blame the switch was the cause of lights being turned on. I was not told nor did I learn of anything being stolen, nor did I see anything out of the way while there myself. As for the Teachers residence this is the first time that I ever heard of or having ever being entered. It is a surprise as the Sister Superior has never mentioned to me.

L. Letourneau
Indian Agent

Sirs,

I beg to inform you that this Department will not assume any responsibility whatsoever for any delay, damages, or accidents resulting from the existence of water in any part of the basement of the new Central School which you are now erecting at Caughnawaga, Que. I consider that it was your duty to take in time the necessary precautions to prevent the admission of water into the above mentioned building, before the advent of rainy and cold weather, such as the closing of the sewer outlet and the artesian well, which you have taken advantage of for your own convenience since its completion. It is unquestionable that you have had ample time since the boring of the well to lay a concrete floor in the basement, entirely waterproof, as provided for by the specifications. Kindly, therefore, undertake at once the necessary work for the drainage of this part of the basement at your own expense, and keep the entire building suitably heated from now until its final completion and acceptance by the Department, as required by the specifications, (Articles 14, 24, & 27 of the General Conditions, also Article 5 under Excavation and Grading.)

I am furthermore advised that the work is progressing very slowly, the roofing not being completed nor the brick veneering which should have been started several weeks ago, when weather conditions were more favourable. It is evident that the building will not be ready for inspection on the date stipulated in your contract, and that the delay will be the cause of serious inconvenience and expense to the Department. I would ask you, for this reason, to give the matter your most serious consideration as to whether the Department can expect the transfer of this building by the end of this year.
I may say that the Department has arranged for the payment of the coke already furnished at the building, (2 tons) this upon the recommendation of our Engineer, also for the rental of a pumping outfit for a period not longer than six days, if so required, this being granted in order to assist you to remedy the present conditions, and allow the heating system to be put in operation with the least possible delay. It should be understood that no other expenses will be paid for by the Department, and the Inspector of Works and the Departmental Engineer are being advised to this effect.

Kindly inform the Department by return mail whether you have made the necessary arrangements for the completion of the drainage system for the building for the date set forth in my letter of instructions authorizing this work.

Your obedient servant,
